review: This is perhaps the most underrated game I've ever played.Slasher's keep is a nearly perfect game in my opinion. If you're into  Hack and slash rogue like type games, this will be perfect for you. This game masters the rpg game play loop. It is incredibly satisfying to level up, get increasingly rare loot, and see that damage value slowly increase over the span of the game. It has high repeatability value, and I still play it regularly even after having beat the game several times. Overall, its an incredibly solid game and you should really play it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060976707', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 381, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 288, 'last_played': 1660967113}
review:
Slasher's Keep is an engaging forward hack-and-slash with tons of fun weapons, abilities, spells, boss battles and enemies! With each play I'm still encountering new items to enhance and change the way I play. As most rogue-likes, the maps change on death or restart so there is a different experience in every go. Additionally, there can be persistence between deaths by using an item chute (maintains special items between runs) and levelling abilities. However, if you're not interested in that, you can play with permadeath enabled, raising the stakes of your run and also improving your skills with the core game mechanics.

I definitely don't feel that enemies are unbeatable as they all have very learnable behaviour, and don't randomly stray away from them (thus far). The weapon swinging does have a bit of learning curve, but once you get into it you can really feel the weight of your actions (especially with heavy weapons), and I like that.

Slasher's Keep has a very simple set of game play rules initially presented to the player, so I would say it's a game that is easy to learn but hard to master.

Dope!

author: {'steamid': '76561198023619939', 'num_games_owned': 566, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 816, 'last_played': 1663008615}
review:
One of my favorite dungeon crawlers. The combat is just right. At first you feel powerless. You can't block, enemies overwhelm you in numbers and come from all the sides. After a while you learn patterns and start to use the environment around you to kill them.

I don't know if I ever finish this game because I am terrible with roguelikes. But it's rare that a game will keep me entertained and come back for more. Losing my gear and trying again is not my style, but for some reason this game has the perfect flow to keep me come back and try again.

author: {'steamid': '76561199107048696', 'num_games_owned': 532, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 511, 'last_played': 1664987222}
review: Im a simp for those sexy posters

author: {'steamid': '76561198041103367', 'num_games_owned': 186, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1574, 'last_played': 1709902237}
review:
I just want to say that I adore this game. It's a very enjoyable roguelite that I am certain I'll spend 100+ hours in over time, despite its flaws.

Most of the negative reviews for this game are either "this game is too hard/I'm bad at this game" and "I obviously do not understand roguelikes/roguelites please hold my hand wah wah". Yes, this game is difficult after a certain point and yes, you do need to grind a LOT. It comes with the genre and it's not the same thing as bad game design.

This game was made by one person; expecting perfection is ridiculous. If you enjoy roguelikes and don't mind some repetitive grinding, definitely give this a go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009634062', 'num_games_owned': 1058, 'num_reviews': 406, 'playtime_forever': 1168, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1118, 'last_played': 1656476235}
review:
Welp, guess im keeping this game cuz the crash launcher opened when I closed the game, annnd the game didnt ever close. SO, with around 2 hours, I can say its.... pretty hard, even when you get the combat down. Easy is unfortunately far to easy but im glad they have it so we can get used to bad guy patterns.

I'd not pay more than 15-20USD, you HAVE to like dungeons though, which I do not unfortunately. Would love to see the artists ideas of the outside world too. Regardless, its good. I was leaning towards keeping it at this low price, and returning to it once its.. more developed anyways.

Beautiful visuals, recommended on that alone. The Videos dont really do it justice as its quite smooth.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027805196', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 1083, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 749, 'last_played': 1655966936}
review:
In the best way, this game is like clearing out dungeons in Oblivion where every bandit might have an awesome item and every chest is an exciting roulette wheel. Crafting weapons helps give a sense of customization and mastery, while the ability to throw items down the laundry chute to your future post-death self means your war chest of equipment grows steadily each run even though it can easily be wiped out by a string of bad luck. 

That being said, first person 3D melee with 2D sprites sucks and there's never a good sense of range. Enemies and traps rapidly outpace your ability to simply deal burst damage to ignore incoming attacks, and the fact that the robust crafting system is only for melee weapons leaves the vast majority of your slots purely up to chance. It's definitely worth a look, and the first rough patches are worth fighting through, but the game definitely has a cap at which point it's just a gear/level check and a frustrating grind to steadily ratchet towards it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019709794', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 197, 'playtime_forever': 2210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1082, 'last_played': 1656615781}

author: {'steamid': '76561198284731206', 'num_games_owned': 1607, 'num_reviews': 505, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 347, 'last_played': 1655379036}
review:
[h1]Enjoy having your progress sent to the shadow realm?[/h1]
[h1]Then you'll enjoy this![/h1]
I think this game would have been way better if it weren't a Rogue-lite game. I much prefer games where you don't lose progress when you die, and in this game you not only have your dungeon progress completely reset but you also lose all your items, some gold, some permanent skills and some permanent levels. I don't know why you couldn't just lose some gold and then respawn like regular games? Why does every indie dev in the past 10years have such an infatuation with perma-death? I simply don't enjoy a game where I lose 2hours of progress when I die.... call me weird, but I just don't. People who play Diablo2 on hardcore might, but I don't... and it's why I can't recommend the game. I was juuuust starting to get a nice few pieces of equipment together and then I got kekd. The game is already extremely punishing with the non-regen of health, so why do you ALSO need to lose all progress? Anyway, I'm done.... uninstalling and won't be touching this game again. I actually value my time and can't have 2hours of my life just sent to the shadow realm like that.

For more reviews, visit my curator page: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/7851637/
For my full recommended list of games: https://steamcommunity.com/id/lfpg/recommended/

author: {'steamid': '76561197976923611', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 604, 'last_played': 1655088268}
review:
This is not a bad game, and you will enjoy this if you enjoy level grinding, but I found this game to be in that category of "way too repetitive." The early stages will become so easy it's just a formality, and then you get to level 5, get killed by something unexpected, and have to repeat everything all over again.

The gameplay just isn't fun enough to do the easy stuff over and over, only to get your ass handed to you and make an inch of progress. Some people may like the grind, but I don't give this game much more of my time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977387878', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 616, 'last_played': 1654739720}
review:
Fun but annoying. The gameplay is the fun. The gameplay loop is the annoying, specifically grinding and praying to the RNG gods for what upgrade you get.

Dropping gear for yourself next run helps but dying while carrying the gear is a huge set back. It becomes a grind to get progress. The vendor has upgrades, but maybe not the slot you need. e.g. shoulders were up to level but boots would be level 1, and vendor had every upgrade except boots.

It can be a bit of slog, even Sisyphean, but it can still be fun with all the set backs. I wish there were better permanent upgrades. Abilities on gear can be kept with permalock points, but other games handle the loop better. This is an ok game yet I am curious where this game goes or what the next game could be. It has potential to be more than what it currently is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198220389393', 'num_games_owned': 614, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 1208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1655275033}
review: Let me just start by saying that I really like this game. The combat is a little simple but there is enough substance to be enjoyable and the core gameplay loop of collecting equipment and tossing excess to future re-imprisoned me is fun. However, I would love this game a whole lot more if my character didn't randomly get stuck at the top of staircases or by the remains of recently destroyed barrels and potion crates. I've lost far too many lives to something which feels entirely outside of my control and unnecessarily gimmicky.

author: {'steamid': '76561198849697539', 'num_games_owned': 412, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 9834, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9174, 'last_played': 1672190890}
review:
Absolutely fantastic. A real hiddem gem. Most reviews I'm seeing are around 10 hours.... as you can see in comparison I enjoyed this game very much. And I really didn't expect to. [Furthest I've gotten so far was Floor 246 on perma-death] 

If you enjoy directional combat (to block you have to actually look where you're blocking jnstead of mind-lessly pressing a button), and dungeon-crawler loot grinding, then I'd HIGHLY recommend giving this game a shot. 

I see people complaining about the combat or the parkour areas. Simply GIT GUD (the chute is a mechanic for a reason). And when you go for a run longer than 10-15 floors the parkour rooms become really nice breaks. Almost like safe rooms with a puzzle and items. 

To keep it short, this is a solo dev project. What he has done is made a very unique dungeon crawler-rougelike, with good crafting, art design, and a really fun combat system. Once you get used to it, nothing beats putting a podcast on in the background and losing track of time. 

Even now the dev is somewhat active (an update every few months), making fixes and adding new additions, such as rooms, weapons, and secret liquid combinations. 

MY ONLY COMPLAINT is I want MORE. More weapons, enemies, rooms, etc.... which is more a compliment than anything.

P.S. Rougelite mode for early game, learning the mechanics and how to best use the chute. Once acclimated, Permadeath runs are where it's at.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003822853', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 948, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 948, 'last_played': 1654835132}
review:
I do not enjoy the balance of this game. Yes, there's a "roguelike" mechanic that requires you to die repeatedly in order to amass the levels you need to continue. But each time you ascend a level, if you haven't acquired a powerful enough item, you're destined to be starting over.

That being said, I love everything else. The quirky designs and novel voice acting amuse me immensely. I actually enjoy the deceptively simple combat and the ample variety of skills and items. The game strikes a good balance between having secrets and making them easy enough to discover. With just a bit more balance I would play this game to the end. I still recommend it, but get it on sale.

review:
Jogo muito bom, mesmo cheio de salas e inimigos parecido, não achei repetitivo.
para usar a varinha é o [C] , acho que no tutorial não fala kk.

Pontos Positivo

1- Você pode criar uma espada ou maça do jeito que quiser.
2- Depositar items para salvar para próxima run caso morrer.
3- Fica mais forte toda vez que morre por causa dos ponto permanente.
4- Tem varias salas secretas, puzzle, desafios, armadilhas, bosses e tesouros.
5- tem poucos bugs, não atrapalha muito tbm, só atrapalha se clipar a parede e morrer caindo. ( aconteceu uma vez só )

E tem muitos outros pontos positivos bons não sitado aqui mas é melhor jogar para descobrir mesmo.

Pontos negativo

1- é dificíl ( mas isso é só jogar e pegar o jeito e ficando cada vez mais forte, a não ser que jogue no modo com uma vida só ai não tem jeito )

author: {'steamid': '76561198945861460', 'num_games_owned': 145, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 2551, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 751, 'last_played': 1663489934}
review:
Плюсы:
-Графика (Увы есть кривые моменты, но идея очень даже хороша)
-Боевая система
-Сюжет (За то, что он есть и читать каждую страницу лора очень даже интересно)
-Система крафта оружия 

Плюс-минус:
-Некая доля фарма
-Музыка (Принципе неплохо, но все равно ставишь что-то свое рано или поздно)

Минусы:
-Кривые моменты (Невозможность найти ключ например или зажимание тебя врагами в углу)
-Бессмысленность больших и более подземелий, ибо ничего не меняется
-Игра очень быстро надоедает, из-за чего после первого или второго прохождения интерес представляют только лорные страницы

ИТОГ 
 Игра на вечерок-другой, после 20-ти часов вам уже все надоест (если не раньше)
6.5 из 10

author: {'steamid': '76561198033004159', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 339, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 339, 'last_played': 1653332708}
review:
One of my favorite hidden gems on Steam. An excellent rogue-lite with a great art style and good sense of humor. The story (told in notes between levels) is intriguing enough to keep going and you keep enough progress (via exp levels and skills) every death to still feel like you're making progress. The movement is somewhat clunky I suppose, but that's kind of the point given the retro approach to the games style. The difficulty curve is very steep, you will die a lot, it can be frustrating, but using chutes (a way of storing items for your next life) and gaining exp/skills you will get stronger every time. It's a rogue-lite, so I dunno how people can complain about starting again after dying. 

Some people complain about controls. There's like 11 keys to remember so I dunno what's up with the complaints. X draw weapon, C draw wand, WASD move, shift sprint, space jump, tab open inventory/character sheet, LMB strike (use WASD to change strike type and hold for power), RMB block (aim at incoming strike to block better) or aim with wand; it's easy really. Hover over items in inventory with your cursor and press a number key to assign a hotkey. Seriously, it takes two brain cells to figure out. 

There's Lots of items, skills, and even weapon crafting. 

You can push enemies (even chain pushing by hitting them into each other) into spikes like M&M Dark Messiah; you can light oil spills on fire, you can lure enemies into traps, break platforms of crates into them, etc. etc. It's good fun.

If you don't mind dying a lot, like rogue-lites, and like quirky tongue-in-cheek style games, then you'll almost certainly like this. It's really a hidden gem with a lot more depth to it then you'd expect.

PS. I don't play with a controller so I can't speak to any issues there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198420499838', 'num_games_owned': 413, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 3886, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2151, 'last_played': 1660478875}
review: Bundan önce de dungeon crawler ve RPG türünde FPS oyunları oynamıştım ama bu oyunda ilerledikçe yeni şeyler görmeye devam ettim. Tabii ki muhteşem bir çeşitlilik değildi ama oyunu oynayıp keşfetmek istememi sağlayacak bir çeşitlilik mevcuttu. Özellikle pasif skillerin çeşitliliği hoştu. Oyunu oynamak oldukça eğlenceli (Oyunda bir yerden bir yere zıplamak ne kadar sıkıntılı olsa da alışınca ve diğer mekanikleri kullanmayı öğrenince bir şekilde eğlenebiliyorsun zıplayamadığında bile) Savaş mekanikleri ve savuşturma başta zor ve saçma gelmişti ancak buna da alıştıkça ve savuşturmak için saldırının geldiği yöne doğru dönmem gerektiğini çözdüğümde savaşmak daha da eğlenceli bir hal aldı. İlk defa girdiğimde ve belli bir miktara kadar seviye atlayana ve birikim oluşturana kadar. Özellikle 4. kattan yani ilk boss'tan sonraki katları geçmek oldukça zordu çünkü düşmanların ve tuzakların verdiği hasarlar çok fazla artıyordu ama imkansız değildi. Ölüp başa döndüğümüzde ise tüm deneyimimizi ve altınımızı kaybetmememiz ve üst katta topladığımız eşyaları ölme ihtimalimize karşın başlangıç katına yollayabilmemiz de ayrı bir güzellik (Tabi permadeath yani kalıcı ölüm seçeneğini seçmediyseniz.) olmuş. Sonuç olarak indirimlerde 10 küsür liraya aldığım bu oyun beni tatmin etti eğer ki siz de dungeon crawler ve RPG türlerini içerene FPS oyunlarına ilgi duyuyor ve bu türde bir oyun arıyorsanız bu oyun size göre olabilir bir şans verin derim. İyi eğlenceler :)

review: I love this games style, game play and general loop. It's such a wonderful game but the reason I'm recommending against it is because it's also very wasted potential. The jump in difficulty from the first boss (Floor 4) up to the very next normal floor is INSANE. The normal enemies suddenly start doing the same sort of damage as the boss and obliterate you instantly. It's not impossible to get past these floors, but... it's certainly not as fun.

review: Combat wasn't fun for me. Just swinging your weapon around hoping to hit the 2d enemies while they are hitting you, rinse and repeat until you die. review:
Beautifully made game. Fun gameplay loop and progression system.

Stands as a work of fine art, given the number of hours and amount of thought that went into creating a singlular cohesive experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198113282068', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 86, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1651923106}
review:
[h1]Main turn-down points:[/h1]

[b]Movement:[/b]
• All movements is to floaty, slow, and uncomfortable.
• Jump is to low and useless. Player can jump over the pit, but can't jump over the fence - why?
• Moreover, the player gets stuck on every little object like a stool, pot, head, and other junk - again, why?

[b]Combat:[/b]
• The range of the player's attack is less than that of the enemy, and I didn't notice an increase in reach when using a larger weapon. They all the same = lame.
• Every mob has a huge reach ( over their visuals ) and bad attack frames -> at least fix the reach pzl.
• Player attacks can miss at point-blank range - reference to the X-COM or laggy hitboxes?
• Or sometimes game just ignores my inputs like jump, attack, and block -> fix the state machine plz.
• Block/Parry is too floaty, again. Despites that block/parry activates on mouse click, this animation don't give me enough visual information -> fix: sharp and fast parry with little overreach animation ( about 0.45-0.75 sec. ), then to the block position = two clear visual sections.
• Sack attack = suck -> fix: make it chargeble to smack mobs harder and cast them further. Addational: at max charge mobs can hit and push aside other mobs. If they hit walls - they stanned for a few seconds, if they hit fence - they fly over = Sack attack now doesn't suck.

[b]Misc:[/b]
I really don't like hidden mobs scaling: the best weapon from the first floor is a toothpick on the second! Thats to fast, besides mobs even don't change visualy, they just got more health and attack power = to lazzy :\
But fix for that leads to rework of all power scaling system. Good example -> "Beneath" mode from the Paint the town red: mobs have static stats, visual power scaling, various strong and weak points.

Come on devs, you at least played the Void Bastards - jump must be higher, animations - sharper with a better "hit", movements more responsive, weapons must have different reach, mobs must have way less reach and have visual differences in power lvl.

After the Void Bastards and Paint the town red - to slow, uncomfortable, and boring. But, it can be fixed pretty easily for the most parts.

author: {'steamid': '76561198116278463', 'num_games_owned': 506, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 616, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 616, 'last_played': 1651685120}
review:
[h1] "Ну всё, это в последний раз!" [/h1]
Каждый раз ты так думаешь после очередного проигрыша, но игра не отпускает, подбрасывая какой-нибудь новый уникальный лут, и вот ты опять на том же уровне, где проиграл в прошлый раз, и уже сильнее чем в предыдущий раз, опять дропаешь уникальный желанный предмет, а предыдущий уникальный шмот (меч, топор, вещи, кольца) ты отправляешь сам себе через специальные местные "магические терминалы" в сундук на будущий забег, так, на всякий случай, чтоб не начинать голяком, в случае проигрыша, но таким образом ты загоняешь сам себя в петлю.. и так может продолжаться до бесконечности.

Игра на подобии Delver'а, но только прокачка классическая, почти как в Diablo 2, и в отличии от Delver'а, не только деньги, но и весь опыт (уровень персонажа) сохраняется на будущий забег.

Саундтрек с мелодиями на какую-то пиратскую тематику не подходит игре, на мой взгляд больше бы подошел эмбиент.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078131526', 'num_games_owned': 1668, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 628, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 628, 'last_played': 1650721392}
review:
There is a lot to love here. It looks good and runs really well too. I love the art style most of all. I'm just not a big roguelike person. I don't mind starting over and losing all your gear too much. There is a chute you can toss gear back to the start which is great. What sucks is that you lose levels so can go backwards. I saw someone else point that out and it wasn't a big deal until it happened to me. This probably wouldn't be a huge issue, but if you die past the first boss without finding a chute you lose all your gear, a couple levels and some gold. Then you can't beat the level 4 boss because you've lost everything so die there and lose another level. The stuff past the boss is tough too. Got a little further but once I lost my gear and had to start with the bottom tier stuff it just got old fast. Now I'm stuck on the first boss again. Fun. 

I would recommend this for people with patience. Lots of patience. The game grips you for a while, but there will likely come a time when you just get sick of it and quit. That is where I am now. May come back to it, but for now I've seen as much as I will of this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198414079365', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 666, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 666, 'last_played': 1648184440}
review: It's a fun game to kill some time with relatively deep combat if you take the time to experiment with it. Most builds feel pretty viable, stats and skills are meaningful upgrades, and the art style is excellent. I do have some problems though; the depth of field is strange and I find it difficult to find the correct spacing and judging the range of an enemy's attack is difficult to judge. I also have some trouble reading some of the text on my character sheet, I can read cursive just fine but the style they went for is difficult to read. I think they should keep the font they have, but maybe add a setting to alter it for people who have trouble reading it. Aside from that, this game is worth checking out and I hope to see it succeed!

author: {'steamid': '76561198274718459', 'num_games_owned': 137, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 915, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 445, 'last_played': 1690140704}
review:
Slashers Keep is a simple rogue lite where you climb a tower. There's plenty of mechanics that interact to allow you to grow stronger, and overall it's not particularly demanding at the lower levels.

The melee system is functional and doesn't overstay its welcome. You hit with a click and can hold for a stronger attack. Enemies will swing at you on a particular interval for what they are, and you can parry them with a right click. Later on this will do more damage and become very very useful. For now it's just nice to avoid the loss of health. 

Weapons swing faster based on what they are, and it overall makes sense. Daggers are quick and low damage, Maces and hammers are slow and high damage. Everything else sits on a spectrum between them. There seems to be knockback and stagger mechanics based on what the enemy is hit with, but it's inconsistent and easy to miss.

You can dodge attacks and traps with movement, so once you have decent gear you can sprint through the first level with a heavy melee strike and chain kill everything you find, and simply step around enemy strikes.

The problems start when you reach more complex rooms. Most of the time you're just in a hallway or square room with maybe a pillar or two to dodge and fight around. Some rooms though feature stairs, fences, loose boxes, furniture, and traps. It's very easy to lose track of the enemy you swung at because they clipped to a higher position due to loose boxes and furniture moving around.

Because Slashers Keep uses a Doom styled 2d sprite system, most enemy models are just a flat sprite that faces you at all times. This means that if they clip to a higher or lower position than standard, they can become very difficult to shoot at, block, or attack in melee.

This isn't a problem in the first rooms, but once boxes and shelves fall over and create more complex and difficult terrain, it rapidly can turn an easy 1v2 fight into an unmanageable mess. This could just be a skill issue.

I've lost many strong characters and runs to a zombie that managed to climb several boxes and continue to hit me from what feels like way to far up for a standing character model to strike at.

The wand system is alright, but I haven't interacted with it nearly as much as the melee. The wands function more like firearms than anything, with an ammo system that is tracked for each individual wand you pick up. There's different varieties that act like sidearms, shotguns, snipers, filling their combat role in a satisfying fashion. However, your melee damage will almost certainly outpace the wands damage immediately, and with the extremely low ammo and inventory space keeping your wands topped up with ammo will be a serious challenge, as will killing anything without needing to reload at least once. It reminds me of bloodborne, where your ranged option isn't meant to deal damage, but is utility for opening up more options in a fight. The problem is that wands here don't seem to do anything aside from deal direct damage. If they staggered enemies then it might be different, but it feels like you're spending a lot of ammo, inventory space for the ammo, and time better spent with your melee, all so you can deal a bit of damage to ranged enemies.

On top of all that, wands disappear when empty and there's no way to recover them. A skill you can acquire early on will prevent them from vanishing, so you can in theory reload them and continue to use them later. You aren't told this skill exists until you encounter it, and it feels like a mandatory skill to even engage with wand combat beyond firing what drops and then returning to melee. Again, ammo will still be an issue, but at least you can hold onto wands that you like, to reload and keep using.

Now, I've mentioned skills a few times, so I'll go into them now. You acquire skills by picking up gear that has them. Early on you'll find simple ones like Melee Life Steal on a sword. This gives a microscopic amount of life steal, but it'll help keep you alive long enough to keep climbing.

The real skill system appears once you have a skill point, which you get every few or every other level. Not sure which. A skill point allows you to take a currently active skill, whether from gear or from having bought a level in it before, and make that one level Permanent. In the melee life steal example, this means you could now drop the weapon and continue to have the small life steal amount with other weapons, and buy more levels of life steal in the future. This is nice because you can essentially find what skills you like, and if you value it enough, buy a permanent level to keep it in other runs. Early on you'll basically be deciding what you want to get permanent levels of from the first few floors. 

I really enjoy the skill system, since it means you get a sense of exploration and wonder when you find a new weapon or armor piece that has a skill you haven't seen before. The fact that it has some permanent progression is nice too, but your mileage may vary on if that's a good thing in the roguelike/lite environment.

Based on the character backstory you chose, you gain a single skill that you can't get any other way. You can't gain levels in the skill either, so it starts as powerful as it will ever get. It could color every run with that character, but they haven't felt that distinctive so far.

An early character, The Prince, starts off with more damage on sneak attacks. Without this skill existing, I wouldn't even know sneak attacks are a thing, since there's no indication of stealth or sneaking being mechanics. A pass of them, or some early skills that make them obvious, such as the eye from Elder Scrolls, might be in order. Crouching to see vision cones could be a good implementation.

Alongside the skill system is the chutes and crafting. Any floor above the starting floor has a drop chute that allows you to send items back down. The purpose of this is to save valuable items for your next run to pick up and use. Most often this means sending down a good weapon and some armor so your next try has an easier first few floors. The best use early on, is to help crafting. You will occasionally find components as loot. These are clearly labeled. There's hilts, blades, axe heads, crossguards, gems, enchantments, and anything you could think of. These can be combined, up to four at a time, to create custom weapons that will hopefully be stronger and more useful than anything you've found. 

Components take up valuable inventory space, and dying with them means they're gone for good. So you might spend a few runs trying to collect components for one very nice weapon, only to craft it and die immediately. Or, you craft it, send it down to pick up next run, and perpetually live in fear of losing it, so you keep sending it down at the second or third floor, never using it to push further up. This is probably just me, since I play like a rat. Currently the crafting system stops at melee weapons, but you can add enchantments and upgrades to wands as well, just not make any from scratch.

Occasionally you'll find empty bottles. These are very useful, since they are the only way to interact with Alchemy. To use Alchemy you take the empty bottle in your inventory, and combine two other consumables into it. This could be ammo for wands, health potions, bombs, and stat upgrades. Some results of alchemy are extremely useful, others are novelties. These aren't random, so finding powerful combinations that grant skill levels you want is a priority.

There's also a random shop from the second level onwards.

Using your crafted weapons, powerful enchanted wands, gear, farmed skills, and hopefully honed experience you'll push to the first boss. That's where I've ended my runs so far, since I'm not experienced enough yet to push past it. By grinding my skills and gear I'll eventually kill it, but for now I want to really explore the lower floors and see what I might have missed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992587371', 'num_games_owned': 663, 'num_reviews': 146, 'playtime_forever': 603, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1676538812}
review:
A nice mix of cool ideas and concepts alongside the usual stuff you'd expect of a dungeon crawler makes Slasher's Keep a real gem with a lot of potential both now and in the future to provide hours of enjoyment. While the visuals may easily be a turn off for some people, it's worth mentioning to anyone unsure that the graphics actually support the game (And allow a certain crafting mechanic to be more effective) more than feel like a easy out for the developer.

However the game does have issues here and there, namely with hitboxes and variety (hitboxes are really silly at times, and once you've done three or four runs through the first tileset youll have experienced just about every version of every room and it no longer feels unique as it does a chore), but issues do arise in other places too. Like the player's jump feels like 10% too short, and some rooms are way too tight for what they send up against you (There are mages that can place buffs on normal mobs so you have to target them first, but it can be in a situation where you can't get past or out dps the mobs so you get stuck in a stalemate that ends you run through no fault of your own) and in addition to that the system that gives it the roguelite-ness isn't really optimally designed meaning that your runs can often feel completely wasted because you gained basically nothing in the grand scheme of things simply because one of the previous issues took you out before you made it to one of the 'pass onto the next run' chutes with an upgrade to pass on.

So, an absolutely solid base for the future, and plenty of fun on its own, but with a dire need to change some things.

author: {'steamid': '76561198296371641', 'num_games_owned': 751, 'num_reviews': 197, 'playtime_forever': 1220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1058, 'last_played': 1692987941}
review:
Addictive. Infuriating.  Buggy.  Strange.  Grindy. Cute.  Silly.  Trite.

Combine those and you get this game.  I dont mean that in any was as an insult. This game is soley unique.  I dont know how to describe the feeling except with those words.  It will not appeal to all.  Its a grindy slow experience that puts alot of emphasis on death and how you prepared for that death and even the game outright says, the RNG will eventually fuck you..

But its the journey.. I find myself coming back time and time again for the unique atmosphere and style.


Definitely a unique game worth playing

author: {'steamid': '76561198119413869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 4481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2465, 'last_played': 1673532082}
review:
Combat is engaging, mechanics are introduced slowly and natively to the setting. No 8-hour long tutorial, just a splash of hints that you can disable with a keybind.

Progression is fought tooth-and-nail for, and the addition of the item chute makes coming back from where the game last kicked your balls in less of a pain if you use it effectively.

Some things I think the game could use:
- Modding tools, however, this is a pipe dream. Damian has stated that he's not even sure if it's possible.
- Anti-grind. Of any kind. Please. Something like starting on later floors if you beat them enough times or decreasing the chance that an item has a skill you've already gained before or... _something._
- In-game clarity on how to unlock the other characters. The Jellyman is esoteric at best and [strike]I haven't even seen the shrine you're supposed to unlock the Demon with. (Am I doing something wrong, Damian?)[/strike] (No, I just needed some luck)
- The difficulty spike after the spider boss could use some smoothing.
- The penultimate floor has a significant and annoyingly large chance to generate a floor which is completely impossible, requiring you to use the "reroll" cheat code quite often.

A list of things I think the game does really, really well:
+ Behold! A combat system more nuanced than "left-click until it dies," but less needlessly complex than "here's 8 cooldowns for 10 special abilities!" They said it couldn't be done.
+ A lore and history is built and presented in a way to the end user that isn't needlessly expositive or hopelessly arcane.
+ Character creation is goofy and neat despite extremely limited options. 
+ Crafting is easy to learn and worthwhile to perform.
+ Alchemy adds another layer of depth to the game and subtly puts a new way of thinking into the player's resource hogging instincts.
+ The Item Chute is a great way to make the next run not suck.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029599355', 'num_games_owned': 523, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 99, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 99, 'last_played': 1642271711}
review:
I'll start with the positives. It looks really good. The graphics are old-school sprite-like but with a modern feel to them. I love the way you can interact with the environment, and shoving enemies into spike traps never gets old. 

The thing that really damns this game is the controls. It feels like you're walking through mud, and the attacks are far too slow. Slow attacks would make sense if you had to time them, but because of the slow-motion of the game you can't do that. Especially the "shove them with your sack" move loses its impact because it's just so damn slow.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030744400', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 134, 'playtime_forever': 4558, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4558, 'last_played': 1641750582}
review:
I like Slasher's Keep. I like it a lot, and I recorded my progress.
[b]Please watch if you prefer a more Audio / Visual presentation.[/b] https://youtu.be/lMALfjzs_vQ

Slasher's Keep is an Indie, RPG, FPS, Action RogueLite that is all about Hacking, Blasting, and Slashing your way through a Procedurally Generated Dungeon, [b]In Beautiful Cell-Shaded Glory! YES! [/b] 

[h1] Think a Procedurally Generated, Cell Shaded, Dark Messiah of Might And Magic! OMG YES! [/h1]
[b]Knock foes into Spikes, down Pits, into Fire, Show em Who's The Boss![/b]
Knock em around! [b]Smashing em around with your Big, Manly Sack! Not Kidding. [/b] 
No Boots of Doom here: in Slasher's Keep, Your Loot is your Secret Weapon! 💰

So Swing away! Smashing and Stunning them with your radically unconventional tactics and power! 💪
Be Unconventional! 👍

[h1] Impressive Environmental Interactivity![/h1] 
The dungeons are packed full of physical and physics based stuff that reaction to your presence, and to the presence of monsters approaching you. 

Crates and barrels block movement and can be pushed around, as can the Explosive Barrels of fun you find, just waiting around for a good whack for a good time. 

Pressure plates slam spikes into any meat in their path, scything blades speed across corridors, acid slimes leave caustic little presents for any unwary feet, turrets fire off bolts of dark energy to blast down any in their path, and more!  

And spike traps are everywhere, just waiting for anyone to push it too far, just like in Dark Messiah, so you know what to do! 💰

[h1] Big Hits For The Big Win![/h1]
Remember to charge up your attacks for more Power. 
Holding that power attack while you sprint towards the moleman or zombie or goblin from across the room to get the sneak attack + sprint bonus on damage helps rip through them pretty quick. 💪
[b]Power Attack FTW![/b]

Those quick little attacks are to finish off weaken foes, or to smash pots, even when you get boxed in, it’s best to still try to charge up the big hits, holding the A or D key Skyrim style when you to swap the area in a cone. It will hit each foe in front of you. 
You are a hero, so cleave through your foes for victory!

[h1]But Be Careful Manly Man! Or Wo-Man! Or Manly Them![/h1]
Though you are a Manly Man, or manly Lady if you wish, your foes hit Hard! 
And healing is sometimes hard to find. So try not to get hit! 
Stick and Move, and remember to at least block if you see a hit coming, as even a moleman can scratch you up something fierce! 

[h1]Plus, the Permadeath is Optional in this Rogue Lite![/h1]
Which is quite the boon, if you're not into the whole dying and starting at the beginning scene. 
With intense, Hack and Slash, First Person Action, Slasher's Keep is a unique Dungeon Crawler that's worth a Look. Look with me?

author: {'steamid': '76561198294619781', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1700883597}
review:
Yes, it's a rather fun game and is quite entertaining, I've only played the lower dungeon levels since I haven't been able to make it further, but I do love the style of the game so far as well as the enemy variation and the crafting component. It's pretty challenging and love the humorous posters that can be found around the dungeons. 

However, there are a few things I would like to see fixed in the future:
- Attack range seems a bit wonky. Enemies who make use of close range melee attacks can sometimes land their hits from far, but your character can never do so.
- If you're walking from side to side and try going up wooden stairs, your character gets stuck on the last step.
- When charging up an attack you can run in any direction except backwards... why?
- The random generation of levels can be quite aggravating, as sometimes you don't come across a smithing station until the 4th or 5th floor.
- Music does get a bit redundant.

Overall a good quality game and would recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198218116192', 'num_games_owned': 501, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 1210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1210, 'last_played': 1640998452}
review:
This game is an absolute gem and I can't believe I haven't heard more about it. Starting out is pretty tough, but you build up your character by locking in perks that you get to keep when you die among other things. You climb as high as you can in the dungeon and when you feel like you're in over your head, you take off all your gear, throw it down a chute, and then plunge yourself into the wolves like you're crowd surfing. Upon respawning at level one, you are bestowed with the delightful goodies you have gifted yourself and may proceed with absolutely slaughtering the lower levels like a proper madman. And the XP doesn't even scale down - you're /rewarded/ for your subsequent rampages! : ) It's a delight

The game doesn't take itself too seriously in a way that feels like you're playing with a really chill D&D DM. My favorite ability is being able to mash up your fallen enemies into weapon components with your bare hands. It's not the most useful one, but it /is/ very funny. My most powerful weapon in my first winning run was a lightning-spirit-fire-ice hammer lovingly crafted and named Egg

My biggest beef would be with the second dungeon type and its horrible, tedious, required (sometimes), timed parkour sections... They've supposedly patched this to not such so bad (sometimes the parkour is ramps instead), but ugh, dude... Worst part of the game, hands down

Regardless, still a big, big recommend! It's worth it full price, there's so much love and care put into this. There's /so/ many things jammed in here

author: {'steamid': '76561198845446507', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1641415590}
review:
This game is very slow, especially for a rouge-like. The game-play loop is very tedious to me, and doesn't have any interactions that aren't surface level. The combat is basic so there isn't a lot of room to really experiment like other rouge-likes

I suggest watching Northernlion play it and if it looks REALLY good then go for it. 
I've watched this game for hours before buying, and tried it because of the winter sale. I have to warn people that what you see is what you get. (Yes I know about the crafting and loot dropping, it's not that cool! Even the bosses are block, bash, hit!)

author: {'steamid': '76561198024287214', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 2778, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2673, 'last_played': 1641335384}
review:
Let me first start by saying I like a lot of things about the game: The general idea, the look and feel reminiscent of first person RPGs of old, the loot system, the gameplay mechanics etc. Figuring out how to clear each room and taking advantage of environment and your character's abilities is genuinely fun.

However, I think the roguelite structure (as currently implemented) does the game more harm than good as it makes the game rely on needless grinding too much. But wait, you say, you mentioned that the gameplay is fun. It is, but only on the floors where the enemies pose an actual challenge. You see, when you reach mid game, clearing the first floors poses no challenge at all. However, you still have to tediously do it each time you restart because if you skip these floors you'll miss out on valuable experience. When you die (as far as I understand the game mechanics), you loose the percentage of your overall stats (not just the "new" stats you acquired during that run), so if you skip those first floors and die, you might actually end up in worse state than when you started.

I wish the game offered unlockable shortcuts every couple of floors to where the challenge/fun is (to compensate, the default dungeon size could be increased), however that would also mean having to change other systems, such as only taking away from the newly required stats.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063055436', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 186, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 186, 'last_played': 1641148768}
review: Addicting game play loop. It sucks wiping but keeping some of your stats, money and anything you put down the chute makes the next run possibly exciting.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084110985', 'num_games_owned': 463, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 736, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 736, 'last_played': 1629690035}
review: Fun small-scale dungeon crawler. Nails the "Explore, Craft, Combat" gameplay loop of stuff like Obliviion and Arx Fatalis. Slasher's Keep also has the same issues the prior mentioned games have: Slasher's isn't very deep, the gameplay is repetitive, and loot sometimes just isn't worth the time it takes to save up or clear a room for it. I'd recommend it with the caveat that you aren't getting a deep, mechanically rich experience like Tales of Maj'Eyal or Diablo 2. If you like the promotional images and don't mind a silly game where you run around and collect loot like a goblin, then absolutely check Slasher's Keep out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137026460', 'num_games_owned': 1255, 'num_reviews': 199, 'playtime_forever': 403, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 403, 'last_played': 1640884599}
review:
[h1] [i] A sweet rogue-lite developed by one person  [/i] [/h1]

Slasher's Keep might initially seem like one of many rogue-something games that oversaturate the market without providing any real value in return but that's where you'd be wrong as the game has quite a few tricks up its sleeves. While simplistic at its core, it does offer a fairly competent procedural random generation of levels filled with decently interesting variety of enemies and loot. Where it truly shines though is its auxiliary mechanics - you have got a good combat system at its core, yes, but you also get a fairly innovative crafting system that let's you utilize all little bits and bobs you have collected throughout the dungeons and put it together to obtain either a weapon that looks competent and believable or a utter mess of components smashed together without any thought that looks like a fantasy DYI project gone bananas - but it will be fun. Slasher's Keep is not a game for tens of hours of immense fun, but it is really good for being developed by just one person and is worth its price, now that it's out of Early Access.

[b] [i] Positives [/i] [/b]

+ Stylized graphics with paint-like art style that looks great
+ Level design, while simple, does its job well
+ Soundtrack - again, quite minimalistic but enjoyable
+ Combat, combined with crafting system, is great - the loot, the attack and block system - its good
+ Enough content for its price

[b] [i] Negatives [/i] [/b]

- All weapons have the same attack patter and animation 
- There is a lot of R&G going on and it often decides the outcome of a run rather than your skill

author: {'steamid': '76561198034464898', 'num_games_owned': 423, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 4268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 928, 'last_played': 1698789359}
review:
This is a "Yes" with one massive disclaimer.

I really enjoyed the game's whimsical feel and gameplay throughout my first few hours of trying to level up a bit, learn the mechanics, and eventually beating the first boss. The next area was rough, a nice spike in difficulty. However, I was then greeted by the true enemy of the second chapter and the part that is preventing me from giving it a fully glowing review.

Platforming.

It's jank AF. Not only are the platforms tiny, but your character can 'stick' and not catch them properly. Then, once you start getting a rhythm, you have to make the another ten to twenty jumps, many in a row. It totally killed my vibe for the game and felt like it destroyed the pacing. The challenge was leveling up, getting stronger skills, crafting and looting better weapons, but now my progression is being blocked hard by something that honestly feels like it should just be removed, retooled, and then added back in. It's incredibly frustrating and then some random generations of the ledge puzzles can FORCE you into doing them multiple times over. This is typically what ends my runs and stops me from returning for a day or two before trying again since you can't progress through a level without doing this.

I also have not found any skills that makes this easier. No increased jump height or movement speed. Height especially would be really helpful.

Other than that, it honestly is a fun game and I can see myself playing for a lot longer, but the platforming is just a monster buzzkill for me. Thought you should know.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997940566', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 49, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1640535549}
review: I waited for this game to go on sale and I'm glad I didn't pay full price.  I had an issue with my mouse not correctly being placed.  I could only select an icon if the mouse was waaay to the left of the icon I'm trying to select.  I looked for a solution to the problem and found that others have had it as well.  I requested help from the dev to solve it but got no response.  Eventually after resizing the screen multiple times I was able to simply BEGIN the game but it certainly didn't solve the problem, it was merely a terrible work around.  I'm requesting a refund.  It's apparent the developer has ignored game breaking bugs and offered no/limited support.  From the very limited and broken gameplay I did experience, it seemed to have slow, clunky controls and one dimensional gameplay.  There may have been a charm to the game style but I was never able to get past the enormous issue of the mouse not accurately selecting icons

review:
Hace tiempo ví este juego y me llamó la atención, y la verdad es que al momento de jugarlo no me pareció gran cosa, el gameplay es torpe, no es difícil como un Dark Souls, que es difícil pero te da las herramientas para completarlo y aprender, este no, es difícil porque los enemigos hacen más numeritos de daño de los que aguantas, te dan un arma al inicio que puede ser más o menos mala, y te echan en una sala con 5 bichos que tiran proyectiles, el poco tiempo que he jugado la verdad no se ha igualado al mismo tiempo que tiré viendo los tráilers.

Recomendado? Solo si el dinero no te importa, a mí sí que me importa, así que lo reembolsé.

review: Recommended for difficult hack and slash since there is considerable meta progression.  No on-demand save and reload is somewhat controversial, but if you exit and come back, you're back on the same level.  Unfortunately, it is the same level, so if you're stuck on a puzzle because the game won't let you map your mouse controls (I have historically used left click for jump), you may need a third-party utility to manage the controls.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036446642', 'num_games_owned': 2569, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 486, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 532, 'last_played': 1629018198}
review:
Es un roguelike en el que si te gusta grindear este puede ser tu juego, como no es mi caso se lleva un gran NO.


Te lo plantean como que tienes diferentes hechizos, trampas en el suelo, armas y secretos a descubrir. A mi me lo pintaron así y la verdad que de 10.

Pero tras 9 horas jugadas tengo que decir que esta fuera de lo que se puede lograr a hacer.

Me he encontrado un montón de mazmorras igualitas, los secretos son escasos y siempre los mismos (botones ocultos, cuadros, pruebas etc...)  la magia brilla por su ausencia y muchas veces es muy mala, teniendo que recargarla como si fuese munición.

La hitbox es algo raro aquí la verdad.

Y lo peor:

EL GRINDEO.

Vas a perder una y otra vez, no por tu falta de habilidad nono, sino porque quizás subes un nivel revisándolo todo y te encuentras con que son los mismos enemigos pero con mas stats. Que quiere decir esto?

Pues que tu arma que quitaba 20 y matabas de 2 toques fuertes, ahora quizás tengas que dar 6. Y por mas que tu quieras creerte dios no lo eres así que morirás. subiéndote así los traits con el libro.

Me parece una manera absurda de alargar el juego haciéndose repetitivo hasta la saciedad.

review:
WE NEED A NEUTRAL BUTTON

While compelling at times, the pacing of this game is just off. Huge difficulty spike in the second area.

It's fun for 5-6 hours, then when you realize that the game bends you over after the first boss, it becomes a grind to get the gear necessary to progress.

Only worth it if you don't expect tens of hours of playtime.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004903022', 'num_games_owned': 299, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 1927, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1927, 'last_played': 1636342212}
review:
First thing I should mention is that I'm not a rogue-like guy. So there are bits I'll mention that fans of the genre can just immediately disregard, I guess. If anything, reviewing this game is testing my own self-reflection because I have very mixed feelings.

The most notable thing is that I have 30+ hours in the game. Only something like... 12-20 was to complete the "story" of the character I chose. My point is that this game got me excited and invested not only to "complete" it, but to play it beyond completion. Which is where my recommendation comes from. Certainly, even at full price, this game earns its worth.

I'll start with story, since I mentioned it. And it's usually something I care about. I didn't pay attention here. It's told via text screens between loading into levels. It's so disconnected from the gameplay that I didn't even realize at first it was talking about my character. You end up seeing the same text over and over due to the rogue-like nature, too, so that makes it feel even more like it's not the same reality that you live in.

The next thing I'll mention is the jank, since everyone makes mention of it. What I felt was that the jank was deliberate. It added- for the most part- to the learning curve of the game. So I don't consider it a downside... sort of. The most noticeable jank had to do with crap being in the way of doors and stairs. Sometimes this seemed like things were misaligned, but it's hard to tell. Clearly the game seemed to have fun making locomotion a chore for the player. The second thing was enemy pathing. They just walk in a straight line at the player. It's funny at first seeing them knock over bookshelves and tables. But it gets eyeroll inducing when they get stuck on EVERYTHING.

The thing that ultimately ruined the game for me was, indeed, the rogue-like nature. Even though this is a rogue-LITE in the sense that you can retain so much after each death that you just get stronger and stronger despite continual failure. At first it seemed clever to me. What an interesting twist on RPG leveling mechanics. But then I thought, "Why not just make the game longer?" Indeed, since you are continually fighting the same enemies and seeing the same rooms, rather than have a 10 room dungeon, why not 100? Just make a regular game where dying sends you to the checkpoint. At some point I died to something stupid. I stepped on an easily avoidable trap and it ONE SHOT me, despite having really good gear. And I was carrying both items for a rare character unlock I had successfully been retaining for my entire playthrough thus far. And I just had that defeated sigh of losing that, plus all the awesome gear I was carrying... and I just gave up. I'll never know why people find the idea of losing progress to be so exciting. I'm guessing there's some correlation to people who enjoy gambling. Hell if I know. So I started a new character (the demon) I had unlocked and UGHHHH starting from the VERY beginning was so much worse. Sorry, but I have other games to play.

So why even play this game? Personally, I'd say it's a fascinating set of systems design and execution. It's a pretty niche experience. Like the dungeon-crawler/looter aspect is there and all, but figuring out how to succeed is really interesting.

Oh, and the second biome sucks. Too many traps, too much platforming. It might be one of my recommends with the MOST warnings/caveats.

author: {'steamid': '76561198206732523', 'num_games_owned': 455, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 2117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1346, 'last_played': 1680667182}
review:
Tato hra je skvělá, zábavná a skvěle se hraje. 
To, jak vyvíjíte svou postavu je unikátní a velmi skvěle provedeno. 
Také je zábavné dělat si vlastní zbraně. 

Ale přesto já osobně tuto hru nedoporučuji. 
V pátém patře se totiž se hrou něco stane. Jako kdyby jí někdo přepnul na ultra obtížnost. 
Mě osobně nevadí obtížné hry. Mě vadí, když hra najednou je těžší o 100% procent a vše vás zabíjí na jednu či dvě rány. A nejsem jediný, komu to vadí. 

Hru si rozhodně kupte a užívejte. Ale fakt jí nedoporučuji.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096863537', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 2702, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2508, 'last_played': 1676701829}
review:
Slasher's keep is a interesting first person roguelike dungeon crawler.
When i first started playing this game back a couple years ago, i never thought to move more creatively or using the surroundings to my advantage and with my recent revisit of the game, i noticed more small boxes to jump on leading to more risky jumps on the railings on room or even jumping on one of the breakable pots. The games got small features that make it better sooooo.

Here's a couple things i noticed:

-traps are hell and a simple solution (certain rooms will have a trap that shoots out dark orbs and usually there is a switch somewhere in the room to shut it off)
-its got lovable jank (enemies might just end up spawning in the stairs in rooms but will pop out)
Also if your melee knockback stat is increased sometimes you are able to knock enemies out of the room (but they come running back through the walls)
-Stat loss is temporary, skills are FOREVER (for real you can keep skills, every other level you get one permanent skill point) but keep in mind you can only put points in skills you already have like from weapons and armor, etc.
-you can run forever, you'r character will pant and in general breathe heavy but you can just keep running forever
-sprinting bonus and sneaking bonus, they are nice but one of them the sneaking bonus is much harder than the sprinting bonus

There is much more i haven't touched on but you get the idea of the game.

I think the game is great and I'm looking forward for whatever content.

author: {'steamid': '76561198373744831', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 870, 'last_played': 1636175566}
review:
EU ACHEI ESSE GAME INCRÍVEL, a gameplay é bem gostosa e fluida, a historia é bem interessante, tem uma variação até que grande de personagens e MUITO variação de armas e armaduras, junto disso é o fato de todos os andares/itens serem PURO RNG (praticamente você pode jogar ele pelo resto da vida se quiser, deixando claro que terminando a historia o jogo libera vários modos de dungeon), eu gostei bastante das musicas e combinam com a atmosfera e ambientes... e a parte mais absurda é que esse jogo todo foi feito por 1 cara só e eu achei isso incrível, pq tem muita coisa nesse game e bastante carinho no projeto. (eu acho FODA que todos os inimigos e itens do cenário são desenhados e você consegue ver eles por todos os ângulos)

Algumas reclamações: a primeira sendo que por mais que a gameplay seja fluida o game tem um leve problema de seu personagem ficar preso no cenário bem fácil e isso acontece constantemente e o segunda reclamação seria o pulo de dificuldade do andar 4 pra cima que chega a ser ridículo o tanto de armadilha e o dano que os inimigos te dão. 

Adendo: não leve meu tempo como o game todo, eu joguei apenas a historia e não tenho muito interesse em ficar jogando todos os modos ou coletar tudo que da, mas eu me diverti jogando e eu vejo carinho no projeto do dev.

Adendo 2: o jogo por mais que pareça um "Roguelike Hardcore" ele tem alguns aspectos da gameplay que deixam tudo muito mais fácil e não frustrante, como o fato de (isso jogando no modo historia que vai do andar 1 ate o 11, sem permadeath ou easy mode ativado) você não perde as passivas que você comprou no livro de habilidades, porem você ainda perde level e status (não tudo obviamente) isso pq você vai ter que jogar os mesmo andares dnv e dnv com isso ficando mais forte e assim conseguindo progredir no game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971445273', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 133, 'last_played': 1634281309}
review:
I was drawn to this game by its distinct visual style and premise of climbing out of the titular dungeon - Slasher's Keep. Unfortunately gameplay itself gets stale quickly. Combat is tedious and repetitive, you just attack and block over and over. There are no special attacks or dodges and ranged combat using wands is pretty shitty.
All enemies feel like damage sponges and you can either push them into spikes or do the attack/parry dance, patiently waiting for enemy to attack so you can parry. There is no sense of progression as with each floor enemies damage and HP goes up so much you either die to the first enemy you fight or just mind numbingly chip away at their health for what feels like eternity. Add to that tiny, cramped combat arenas that don't allow much freedom in tackling the encounters. Very often you'll be pushed into the corner by the group of enemies and ganked, cause combat system isn't really suited for fighting multiple enemies at once.
I get it that its a roguelike and there is a persistent character progress between each run, but it just feels so insubstantial. I played plenty of other roguelikes that have satisfying combat that doesn't make you feels like its mandatory to die over and over to restart the game and progress your character (City of Brass and Dead Cells come to mind).
Slasher's Keep isn't a terrible game, its just tedious to play and despite unique visuals there isn't much here to keep me playing. We are so spoiled for choice when it comes to roguelikes that its not really worth playing this one. I can't recommend this game unless you are a big roguelike fan. Its pretty cheap and might be worth getting on sale if you are desperate for just another roguelike.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089348041', 'num_games_owned': 528, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1109, 'last_played': 1696824118}

Just a truly handcrafted game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059958219', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 755, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 563, 'last_played': 1637201520}
review: Slasher's Keep is one of my favourite ways to induce rage-quitting anger. Sometimes, after a long day helping clueless customers at work, I apparently want to unwind by angrily swearing at my computer as I die once again due to my own stupidity or lack of attention. Also there's goblin porn.

author: {'steamid': '76561198872718625', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 104, 'last_played': 1633303433}
review: I had no idea how good progress felt before playing this game. Somehow, the game makes getting stronger actually feel like getting stronger. Progression is done so well and it makes seemingly unbeatable enemies become nothing but a hurdle on your next milestone. The combat system is unique and actually rewarding. My dopamine levels shoot up when I first kill an enemy with a lot of health. This is a dungeon crawler done RIGHT! Amazingly simplistic combat and an incredibly entertaining art style!

author: {'steamid': '76561198046637696', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 1179, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1177, 'last_played': 1648417587}
review:
It's a good game and a fairly difficult game at that. My biggest gripe is mainly that the gameplay is very simple and there isn't much more than what you see in the trailer here on the storepage. It almost feels a bit unfinished, like there's so much more that could be added to it. Maybe if magic was made more viable overall and then you have a magic build up, I pretty much only use wands if an enemy is out of reach.

There aren't any major differences between the different characters other than beginning with a different skill, which sucks. If I pick a big sasquatch, surely I'd hit harder overall.

The gameplay eventually just feels like more of the same because it really is just, find a good weapon, whack some enemies, get to the next floor and immediately try to find a new weapon because the one you had will most likely be obsolete.

It just feels a bit hollow, like it looks really good, but it gets stale pretty quickly in my opinion just because after a while it just becomes a slog.

I'd say get it, if it gets even more free content updates (Although it hasn't had many), or if it's on a substantial sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197961509326', 'num_games_owned': 5571, 'num_reviews': 88, 'playtime_forever': 237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1634358480}
review:
For days and days he slept
and when he finally woke he looked up and his gaze fell up a figure in the mist
and that figure extended his hand and as the man reached out to grasp it he was struck down and back to sleep he went, for another day or five
and as he opened his eyes he saw yet again the hand extended
and once more he reached out to be struck down
and all this went, sleep, wake up, get knocked out for a thousand days or years but the man's faith never wavered and he reached for the hand each and everytime
and his head grew sore from the beating and he grew a great horn on his head where he was struck
and after sometime he woke and he reached out and his torturer gripped his hand tightly and he pulled the man to his feet
and still the man spoke no ill of him and asked not why instead his horn was broken off and melted before his very eyes and it was poured on his skin until it engulfed him whole
and then that shell on him grew darker and green and then red and finally golden because you see the man was rewarded for his devotion
and now the two stood one before the other as equals they stood for a day or so until the winter came
and the man who once stood his master now bowed before him and then they felt on the ground face down and fell asleep
and so did all the other people of the mound as far as the man could see
and then in a days time or a week one by one they would wake and the man wandered the mound striking them down as they tried to grab his hand and the man did his duty as the seasons passed him by until he came by another man in the autumn who did not sleep who did not lie he spoke to the man he said "Be gone!" and the man went and gone he was and when the weather turned it put and tore open the sky then came an ill wind and it shoved him over to his knees he fell and his slits grew heavier until he fell into a deep slumber

author: {'steamid': '76561197998099970', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 280, 'playtime_forever': 1075, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 297, 'last_played': 1657723728}
review:
The game is an absolute blast, loved every minute, BUT.

Well into the game, there is climbing by **jumping around a tower with timed steps**. 
Hate those so much.
Climbed that tower, not so difficult, but when I found 2 towers more complicated in the next level, I uninstalled.
So, if like me, you detest timed jumpings, think if you want to buy it.
If not, buy it.
The constantly appearing "FACE" popup when meleeing enemies, breaks the immersion. Thanks.

SOLUTION FOR JUMPING: Cheat Engine SPOILER !!

On ground, search 4 bytes, exact, 256.
On air (get a pause with alt tab to cheat engine) search 0.
Repeat a few times: the correct address ends in 0, freeze it ticking the square box.
While frozen, you can stack jumps, climbing in the air, with a very slow fall.
Untick to go back to normal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000276114', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1631972692}
review:
This game is great at many levels, but combat - basically, a core element of the game - sucks big time.
It is tedious, repetitive, not visually attractive. And this is what you'll be doing for the most of your play.
Also, scaling/levelup system is just plain boring. Almost each new room you have to switch to new clothes/stuff just to get +1 of something, like a homeless dude constantly picking up a bit better junk every time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044040958', 'num_games_owned': 272, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 626, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 626, 'last_played': 1611764697}
review: Great game really enjoyed the few runs that i've done and cant wait for updates in the future! Would recommend if you enjoy looter rogue likes and a good challenge the combat is pretty cool blocking directional attacks and all. The art style is very unique also there's a really cool weapon creation system all and all is very a good game and it was made by 1 guy keep up the great work Damian!

author: {'steamid': '76561197991825315', 'num_games_owned': 2780, 'num_reviews': 696, 'playtime_forever': 688, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 688, 'last_played': 1632137814}
review:
its cool, has lots of interesting things happening on it

pros:
-gorgeous visuals
-good enemies to fight, they are simple but they work
-progression is very nice
-difficulty is well balanced
-combat is decent

cons:
-world visuals are a bit repetitive
-procedural doesnt create super interesting dungeons to look at
-iventory bash instead of kick, pretty weird decision
-inventory system is a bit rudimentar but it works
-combat is decent but needs to be against smarter enemies to be more tactful, its sad that its not very technicall and most enemies only have one attack and if  they move they just move towards you.
-due to its roguelite nature, late game content is gate keeped by how patient you are. you can save in between sessions but you might die and lose your whole progress so its only worth if you have to close the game.

its cool, hope it becomes something much more. bad thing about roguelikes is that they have nice mechanics, but its a saturated genre that barely create worthy singular experiences. while the game Rogue was pretty basic, we now have a much higher quality standard set by games like CataclysmDDA, Dwarf Fortress and CavesOfQud. this game could work if they tried something mroe system shock with a narrative driven system to back it up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013917525', 'num_games_owned': 350, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 687, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 641, 'last_played': 1669623112}
review:
This game is my favorite title of the year.

The combat is phenomenal, and the depth included with perks, weapons, crafting, etc. is unmatched.

This game is hard at first, but the more you play it, the more rewarding. When I started I could barely make it to the 3rd floor. Now I can get pretty damn high up in the floorage on a permadeath run.

The progression system in place for non-permadeath runs is so good, you can throw items down chutes if you think you might die, and those items go down to the first floor for your next run. This adds a sort of strategic way of thinking about your next life while still on your first.

author: {'steamid': '76561198997479351', 'num_games_owned': 23, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 3698, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3305, 'last_played': 1651758010}

author: {'steamid': '76561198003089798', 'num_games_owned': 1222, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 711, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 490, 'last_played': 1691105821}
review:
Let me preface this by saying I REALLY wanted to like this. It's a charming, unique and well-polished indie game, and I honestly feel bad for leaving a negative review, but the issues this game has with it's balancing leave me with little choice.

There's a lot of good ideas in here, and a lot of things that work well. The artstyle and music is great, the combat feels good and responsive, and the roguelike mechanics are well designed.

However, out of all the roguelikes I've played, this is one of the worst cases of balancing I've seen. The standard difficulty feels akin to "Very Hard" in most other games, and this stems from a terrible scaling system. By floor 3, if you haven't gotten lucky enough to find a decent weapon (which has been a very rare occurence) you'll have to get used to trading blows with basic enemies for what feels like an eternity. The philosophy behind the scaling model seems to be to make enemies as spongy as humanly possible with each floor increase. This gets incredibly frustrating when you get locked into room with 4-5 enemies. Enemies hit like trucks and you hit like a wet noodle. Even with a high level, good perks, a high armor rating, it doesn't feel like it makes any difference at all. Even the lifesteal perk heals next to nothing.

I can only imagine this was made more for players with a masochistic mindset who enjoy gameplay bordering on unfair. If that's your cup of tea, this game should be able to scratch that itch quite competently. For players who are looking for a more casual or middle-of-the-road challenge, I sadly cannot recommend Slasher's Keep.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049780739', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1539, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 941, 'last_played': 1632259755}

author: {'steamid': '76561198042721306', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1630140716}
review:
I expected more from this game.
Starts off as a fun little dungeon-crawler RPG with interesting mechanics and complexity, but it all quickly grows to wear in the gameplay loop. 
The ramp-up from one level to the other is HUGE, you seemingly face the same enemies in each level, except that they grow tremendously stronger, meaning you have to fully explore the previous level to increase your chances. This wouldn't really be a problem for a roguelike, but when dying means you have to start all over again, scrupulously exploring each level time and time again instead of moving forward feels like a chore.
Upon arriving on a new level, your first goal is to immediately find a new weapon to compensate for the ever-increasing enemy health pool, something not always possible since the first room you find might leave you locked in with a throng of enemies with  no means of escaping.
The game encourages grinding, with every death making you lose a slight amount of progress, but still not enough to knock you down back to null. This is very redundant in a game of the roguelike genre.
Combat feels very slow, aiming is clunky. There are plenty of other games in the genre that very able to combine stuff like kicking, directional parrying/attacking with fast-paced gameplay, but it all comes to a slog here where to most effective way is to hold LMB and swing a charged-up attack, wait, hold LMB  and again and repeat.... *sigh*
One other gripe I have with this game is the unnecessary physics engine that only serves to inhibit the player - items getting stuck underneath the player, blocking movement etc.

It's a real shame, because the game's artstyle is fun and some of the detail in this game is really exceptional, but my listed downsides far outweigh the good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069676866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 320, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1629943387}
review:
Multiple times, the game has glitched in a fashion that I can't equip or use any weapons, locking me entirely out of advancing; there is no autosave, so unless you have a recent save, you need to start the floor all over again when this happens.

Don't bother buying it, but if you got it for free, it's worth checking out for an hour or two.
