author: {'steamid': '76561198088841952', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 8237, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4883, 'last_played': 1630962798}
review:
Great game that I got myself absorbed in for hours. Has a fun loot generation system and a rewarding weapon customization system. The potion crafting and amount of skills were surprisingly in depth and the art was lovely. 

Slashers Keep kinda works like a Roguelite in which you keep some skills, levels, and items that you purposefully saved beforehand after you die. This lets you keep running up the gauntlet as many times as you like so you can grind and come back more powerful every time.

Definitely under recognized as a game in my opinion.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966347934', 'num_games_owned': 959, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 3947, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1831, 'last_played': 1630318926}
review: This game has absolutely no right to be as good as it is. A sometimes very fast paced, sometimes slow and methodical dungeon crawler that will make you die again and again just to come back better again and again. A surprisingly vast amount of content that often feels a bit rough around the edges but will nontheless keep you coming back for more loot, more skills, more characters, more challenges. author: {'steamid': '76561198008332774', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 468, 'playtime_forever': 1101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1101, 'last_played': 1628945325}
review:
One of the most frustrating roguelike/dungeon crawlers I've ever played.

Art style and overall mood is great, good amount of various upgrades - too. But other than that this game is a big oof.

First zone is fun and enemies/environments aren't as frustrating. The second zone is like a big middle finger. Lots of spikes, lots of extremely frustrating platforming, where missing a single pixel makes you go down to the ground for a frustrating repeat. 3rd level with its books and code search are also bleh. And most levels require you to find a silver key in order to open the exit door. Sometimes you have to run around the level looking for that one particular monster with a key which you somehow missed earlier.

The leveling system and the way to get stronger - is very very slow and methodical. You literally have to sacrifice every few levels just to restart and grind experience for your character's level increase and to gain some additional skill/attribute points. It just prolongs your suffering. 

I think the leveling-up should be much more player-friendly and much less grindy for this game to feel much much less abnoxious to play for longer period of time. A player should be able to complete a run in a single sitting. And if a player likes what he gets with this game - just let adjust the difficulty the way one wants to suffer while playing this... game.

p.s. I found 86 FoV is in a pretty good spot not to get motion sickness.

author: {'steamid': '76561198023428368', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1741, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1278, 'last_played': 1632164698}
review:
Jeu vraiment vraiment vraiment fun :)
Au début, on se dit WTF, mon perso bouge comme un bateau ! Et c'est vrai !
On commence et on se dit, la vache, WTF les mobs !
On peut mourir très vite, mais on revient. On apprend par l'échec et on avance !
Ce jeu est très addictif, amusant et difficile. Il faut être attentif à chaque moment quand on entre dans une pièce.
Mourir n'est pas une fin, il faut juste prévoir sa défaite et revenir plus fort qu'avant ;)
Je le conseille à tout ceux qui aime chercher des items / défis / XP / Level / Fun
Petite note très sympa, on peut fabriquer ses armes, avec les délires associés ;)
@Author : Your Game is so good !! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198004625267', 'num_games_owned': 3306, 'num_reviews': 227, 'playtime_forever': 818, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 818, 'last_played': 1628357506}
review:
Verdict: Recommended with a discount as the game clearly needs more content and balance

+
Steam trading cards (3 drop, 5 to make a badge)
Steam achievements (30, require a lot of grind)
6 different characters to pick from (2 are from the start and 4 are unlocked)
Passive skills are really interesting game design
Roguelite is well done
Crafting is really interesting and you see everything inserted in the weapon 
Weapon and armor designs are really cool in the late game 
I love the character menu and how everything shows on my hero
After you finish the game for the 1st time you can make runs of custom length
I kinda like the risk-reward and in between runs progression 
One of few 1st person rogue lites 
Mainly melee-oriented with a lot of weapons and playstyles to pick from
Different story for every origin (told in between floors)

-
The different characters are only making different noises and start with a different passive
The ramping of difficulty feels off and you will get into a point where you are one-shot by any trap 
No narration of the story and very little voice acting overall 
Unintuitive stats - required stats are at random, it is not like heavy weapons would require strength and wands intelligence 
Too many "what the hell is this" rooms with a gazzilion traps going through enemies and ranged enemies sitting in the back
Insta dead pits in every other room
Only 2 bosses (at the end of the first biome and at the end of the last one)
Basically no enemy variation - you will see the same few enemies from level 1 to the final boss 
In recent patch notes the developer stated mod support is out of question 
It seems unlikely the game will get more content from the patch notes

+/-
If you die you are penalized by loss of stats, levels, and skills you didn't lock

author: {'steamid': '76561198042103654', 'num_games_owned': 2179, 'num_reviews': 111, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1627913289}
review:
Too deeply early access feeling, much of the menu options require MASSIVE tweaking just to make it playable, and even at that only barely.  I was interested in it when I saw the weapon crafting pic from the preview images, but never ran across any kind of crafting and with how barely functional the game is, I doubt I'll ever have the drive to reach it in its current state.

Just to pinpoint a few problems.
1) The menus go off the edges of the screen in every direction, left side, right side, bottom side... actually, they never went off topside, so I'll give it that.
2) The mouse doesn't click where the cursor is.  In character creation it was clicking about a third of the screen to the right of where the cursor was at, and it didn't show up in the first menu at all, requiring me to use a controller to play.
3) Control aiming with camera is horribly off, I had to adjust the Y axis to about 70% of the X axis to make it feel even remotely close.
4) Control use in the inventory is borderline impossible, to choose a dagger I had dropped beside an axe I had to actually pick up the axe and move it out of the way, because it would always jump past the dagger to the next item no matter which direction I came at it from.
5) Swapping between mouse and controller works horribly.  Often in games where the controller is lacking, I'll grab for my mouse to do things like inventory management, and it simply... Didn't work in my attempts, the cursor didn't show up again when I tried.

author: {'steamid': '76561198250544676', 'num_games_owned': 3672, 'num_reviews': 323, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1627848150}
review:
This looked like being fun from the trailer, but honestly: watch that instead, as you'll see everything the game has to offer.

It's a first-person dungeon crawler, and is pretty basic. You can stab, bludgeon and parry with melee weapons, shoot spells with ranged weapons, and finally can knock back enemies with your swag bag. This can be used to shove them into spikes, or off platforms, and is fun, but fiddly to get right.

At first you don't do much damage, can't take many hits, and things like the magic-casting weapons have limited ammo. As you progress you can level up, and with each death some attributes are transferred over, and some are lost. So grinding is key to getting better here, and then finding bigger, better loot.

This progress makes it easier to play, but doesn't change it up very much. In a linear game you'd probably not die so often, or can start from a save point, so whilst the fundamentals aren't dissimilar, you aren't constantly reminded it's the same thing over and over again. 

Or the narrative, or set-pieces, break up the flow. You don't get that here: you die, and you re-start, and it get's boring quickly. It's fun for a bit, though having played two types of this game in a row (Delver being the other), and having bounced off of them hard in a short period of time, I see now that this isn't the genre for me. 

Fundamentally this is the same as Elderborn / Dark Messiah / Underworld Ascendant / Kingdom Come Deliverance / Dying Light etc etc, in that you stab / block / shoot etc, but randomising levels and enemy placements is no substitute for depth, exciting combat, atmosphere, stealth, an interesting narrative, or set-pieces. 

Or preferably all of the above, such as Dark Messiah manages (if you're forgiving about it's dubious story, at least).

And this has none of those, bar the mildly enjoyable fighting which you''ll experience the entire range of within ten minutes of picking it up. It's not fair comparing a title that barely counts as "indie" against C to B, to A, to AAA titles, but for maybe twice the cost you can get a game that is ten times better.  It might be crushing a lone devs dream to say so, but you can't argue with maths and facts. 

If I spend £30 to £40, then I'd expect at least 20+ hours, or more, from a decent RPG or melee / FPS game. This has cost me about a £1 in a bundle, and after an hour I can't be bothered with it. If I'd paid full price I'd want a refund, because it gets so samey and boring.

If you can't afford the more expensive examples of what I would call a "proper game" then this is okay, but there's plenty of games with the substance that this genre (in my experience) lacks. That's two for two now, and so far my response is...."meh"

author: {'steamid': '76561197984228901', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 281, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1668024037}
review:
Slasher's Keep is a quaint little roguelike, with a unique style and combat system that feels like a cross between Dark Messiah and a retro FPS. Despite some flaws and the dreaded mid to late game slog that these roguelikes tend to have have, its a fun game with some interesting ideas.

Story is meaningless, in my 20 or so runs, i have 0 idea why im in a dungeon, or why i need to go up instead of out. Some lore is shown in loading screens, but i hit play the second i can which on my SSD, is like 2 seconds so i rarely read more than 3 words. 

Graphics are a very nice hand drawn style. Everything is colorful and vibrant, this isnt Legends of Grimrock where everything is dark and grim. If it werent for the blood and decapitations, it would be a pretty cute little game.

Combat is hit or miss, depending your tolerance for BS. Melee swings are very hard to read distance, so you WILL miss a good number of strikes on even point blank targets. Ranged weapons are fine, but this isnt a shooter, even the best wand is cumbersome to use sometimes. Some features like sprinting or sneak attacks seem to be random, there is no sneak button so its pretty much walking up behind something and hoping they dont notice you before your strike hits for a little extra damage. Everything works fine, but i wouldn't say this game has great combat even when everything is working.

As a roguelike fan, i have experienced many mid-late games in the genre, and most of the lesser known ones all seem to have a pacing problems near the mid-late sections. This game does have permanent upgrades like perks and stats, but you lose stats on death, and although perks are pretty useful, you need stats to equip stronger gear and weapons to even have a chance in higher levels. Alot of my runs end around 3-5 levels in, enemies turn into sponges and hit like trucks, so half the time you're trying to cheese everything with ledges or traps, but the hit detection is so odd, half the time you miss point blank strikes, leading to taking half your health from a zombie or mole-rat thing.

This game is brutal, and reminds me so much another game i sunk too much time into before i realized the fun is gone and im just playing because im bored and want to finish and be done forever with it. I do enjoy this game, but i feel like in order to progress higher and win, i need to farm levels and play the first levels WAY too much, and although i do think this game is fun, its not THAT fun. 

Im going to recommend it, only on the basis that it wasn't ever in early access, is only $14, and clearly alot of effort was put into it to make it unique and fun. I respect devs for trying something new, even if its not amazing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197968471816', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 3534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3534, 'last_played': 1626564522}
review:
Interesting and charming art direction, servicable but tired/unoriginal sound effects and novel twist on the roguelike genre. One can see that [i]initially[/i] there was lots of attention to detail. Artistically, at least. And the tiny little bit of music is okay.

The rest is still a looooong ways off of even becoming half-baked. The AI is totally braindead and not even able of the most basic pathfinding, other than running at you in a straight line. Some will even just casually step into bottomless chasms. The enemies will be utterly and completely unaware of and unable to deal with any and all obstacles in their beeline towards you.

Chair/vase/whatever in the way? They don't know what to do. They won't smash breakables to clear their way and even though they can push movables, they can't actually make any intelligent use of it. If the blockade is accidentally and unwittingly pushed aside by the enemy's movement, good. If not, they'll just run in place interminably until [i]you[/i] clear the blockade for them.

If it is another enemy that's in the way, you're out of luck as well. They're oblivious to each other's presence and will neither step aside nor alarm each other.

The aforementioned novel twist forces you to replay the first couple levels over and over and over until you overcome the gating on level 4 (first boss)... of course, playing mostly the first couple levels over and over and over is kind of par for the course when it comes to roguelikes until you get better.

But most other roguelikes that I have played and [i]enjoyed[/i] playing have much more variety and bigger levels. The levels are tiny and you go through the same tiny procedural building blocks over and over and over and over... everything is sooooo samey and boring once you've done it 5 dozen times. To be clear: this game gets extremely repetitive, grindy, boring and frustrating [i]very, very quickly.[/i]

I have now spent about 60 hours. Unevenly distributed among these 60 hours are 5 hours that I learnt something new, a further 5 hours enjoying what I've learnt. The remaing 50 were spent on repetition, frustration, bewilderment and boredom.

The dev seems not to care anymore (if at all, judging by his adversity to/ignorance of feedback, not having responded to the "bug report" thread in over half a year), having already proclaimed his being fully focused on some other projects.

I paid about 9€ on sale and don't think it's worth it. 5€ non-sale would be about right for the amount of fun I had to forcibly wring out of this one over a way-too-long time period.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969490777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 447, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 427, 'last_played': 1626580936}
review:
If you are a hardcore gamer that absolutely loves to be punished, then by all means, this will be a wonderful experience for you. 

Don't expect to get any achievements on Easy difficulty, though. Apparently, you are not welcome to such a luxury for purchasing the game. 

As for the default difficulty, I wonder if the developer even saw the massive drop off in the player achievements attained after the first boss. Clearly there is an issue when the majority of players aren't progressing past the first 4 to 5 levels of the game.

The game was very enjoyable for about 6-7 hours. That's the point where I defeated the first boss. Now, if you thought the game was difficult up till this point, the next area is pretty much doubled in difficulty. I lost all motivation to continue slogging through the first 4 levels just to get back to that point again.

The deal breaker for me was that the first boss is not some kind of checkpoint. If you die after that, you still have to start all the way from the beginning again.

In summary:

- You become powerful over time. The enemies fear the very sound of your grunts echoing through the halls.
- You beat the first boss and feel a sense of achievement! (If you aren't playing on easy mode. Heh.)
- Your legendary weapon forged by your own hands now hits like a moldy wet rag.
- Your godly armor you found in questionable places now feels like you are wearing moldy wet rags.
- The new area's inhabitants think your Halloween costume is cute.
- They make quick work of your trick-or-treating ways.
- You wake up in your jail cell feeling weaker and unable to use your less wonderful wet rags.
- You decide not to celebrate Halloween anymore.

I'd recommend reading several reviews and watch some videos to get a complete understanding for the game to know what's up. I wish you good luck. You're going to need it.

review: This game is incredibly fun. It's artstyle is super charming, its tone reminding me quite a bit of Void Bastards (which is lovely). And overall its gameplay loop is pretty solid. It is definitely a tough game at first, but that is certainly the point, although it isn't anything like "FRUSTRATINGLY" tough. You get stronger and stronger as time goes by and experiencing several deaths as well as the ability to toss equipment from higher floors down to the starting jail cell, which makes deaths on the upper floors not as scary. Crafting powerful weapons is incredibly fun as you mix and match powerful parts and gems to create some truly wild weapons. The combat is pretty straight forward and simple to get into. There are definitely some annoying enemies, but as you learn the timing of their attacks it becomes pretty second nature. But essentially the name of the game is "GET BEEFY". Super fun experience that I have come back to several times.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080435169', 'num_games_owned': 1908, 'num_reviews': 277, 'playtime_forever': 317, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 189, 'last_played': 1630119355}
review:
holy hECC
Seriously this game is amazing its so much fun, the combat style is unique and the challenge is great

Visuals are really new to me, never had much experience in 2D models in a 3D world before that were done as good as this one 


Its neat, you block enemy attacks by pressing right click on mouse while aiming your weapon towards the area they are attacking from, this makes blocking really fun and requires good reflexes

So far I havent gone past the first boss, the curve goes up a LOT after that which I love

This is a roguelite, aka it has progression
If you die you keep your level, you lose the current items you have and some gold and some stats like 1-2 str or whatever.

You can store weapons in hatches and they will be ready for you in the beginning of the next run, so you  throw stuff there to start the next run with great gear if you already have something else 

Honestly I got this game for $9 on the summer sale and I am having a blast, this game is great 
10/10 Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010443359', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 461, 'playtime_forever': 2225, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 149, 'last_played': 1627433426}
review:
Beautifull roguelike game, it's really fu**ing fun.
Basically if Chivalry and the serie Archer had a roguelite baby.

Edit : 
Changed to negative sadly, but it's still a really good game imo, it just need more work.
After beating the first boss, the difficulty become really nonsensical especially if you play in permadeath.
The enemys suddenly become bullet sponges and they do a sh*t ton of damage, even tough you level youre character and get geared as much as possible.
The difficulty curve is trough the roof, I like my games to be difficult but make it at least make sense, it shouldn't ramp up that much that fast it should be way smoother than that.
Also reusing the assets of the first biome is really lazy, like the rat, they use him later in the game with a huge hp and damage buff but it's still the same rat visually, he isn't even geared.

Edit 2 : Gave up on trying to finish the game on permadeath normal difficulty after loosing a game due to a game breaking bug several times  where suddenly I can't run, open the menu and the inventory for no reason. 
I alway get that bug in the middle of a combat late game, I absolutely don't know what trigger it.
I'm suposed to run to avoid bullets but I can't run, I can't open the inventory for the invincibility potions and I can't open the pause screen to quit the game to reload, so I die and and get punished for playing permadeath on a sh*t buggy game.
There is also the famous bug where the goatman hit obstacles but don't stop and get his cooldown like he's suposed to, so he keep charging non stop toward you until he hit you.
Combine that with the ridiculous difficulty curve where you get one shoted by almost anything and you get a mess.
I'm seriously done.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975930822', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 99, 'playtime_forever': 3191, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1032, 'last_played': 1666163555}
review:
my frist review after 17h of gameplay i did not reccomend this game,

The Update!
After an additional 48h and a insaine Quality of life update and patches, has made this game fun! I have decided to re-review the game with all the new work put in to it. To be fair it is a bit of a grind fest, but it feels far more balanced this time around. I have been dying a lot less because of enemies being a way higher level than me. They have fixed the scaling issue. They have added crafting for potions and other mystery things to consume or throw. The map layout has been patched, No more dead ends with unbeatable floors.

Gameplay!
This game can get repititve on a inferno run, But i think the mindset is to not try and grind it all out in a day. Its a test of endurance. One small mistake like falling in to a pit, or not healing at the right time can send you back to the start. I wish there were more unique looking enemies, Right now the loot goblin is by far my faviourte mob/boss. The 2nd area dosent have a boss, but you fight a giant spider at the end of the first area and final boss at the end of the third. Feels like its missing a boss. The enemies get repititve in there looks by the time you hit the third floor. Its all the same looking mobs. I think giving them armor they could drop if defeated would help with this, along with giving new ways of gaining loot. The crafting in the game was confusing at first, but makes sense once you find out the 3 skills you should permalevel for it.

Overall id reccommend this game with the recent patchs. If you think the trailer looks fun, and you are a fan of first person hack and slash games give it a try!

author: {'steamid': '76561198282868808', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 8365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3075, 'last_played': 1702592739}
review: Slashers Keep is a dungeon crawler with first person melee and ranged combat. After you bust out of a dungeon to begin the game, you must progress up the levels of the dungeon fighting the enemies within it, to eventually reach freedom. As you do this you gain new levels, stats, perks, and most importantly weapons. The floors of the dungeons, enemies you encounter, perks you get, and weapons you come across are always randomized giving the game a ton of replayability. The game has great character to it also; the levels look great and change as you progress up the dungeon, the music SLAPS pretty hard, and there is tons of interesting story about your character which you can read as the next level loads. I highly recommend this game, I find myself coming back to it every other weekend or so and having a great time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061647369', 'num_games_owned': 111, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1008, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 965, 'last_played': 1622346963}
review:
Good concept, the combat system is really good (albeit a little weird with 2D sprites but I can understand that for development purposes). It feels weighty and aiming at the enemies weapon to parry is really fun. I was hooked for the first 10 hours.

Progression is just awful though. You come to multiple points (specifically the first few times you encounter the second and third stages) where your stats just aren't good enough and you will find that you are hitting enemies 10+ times with power attacks to kill them and you will just randomly get insta-killed to something. You'll have to spend your time bashing your head into the same 5 enemies slowly leveling your stats (as you lose a bunch of them on each death) until eventually you do enough damage and have enough health to reasonably take on the later stage enemies just to find yourself in an unwinnable situation the next floor and have to do it all over again. This problem may be remedied with a proper build, but that is so hard to do considering the perks you find on gear and getting a point to permalearn one comes down to leveling  and getting one randomly or completing one of the quests (some of which you can do within 2 rooms and others you can't complete if you don't get the right conditions). Basically you're going to be going through the same 3-6 floors numerous times fighting the same few enemies hoping to finally be at that point where you have good enough stats to brute force your way through.

First 10 hours of this game were extremely fun, the next 5 were a slog. I genuinely want to like this game but I can't if the progression stays this way.

For 14 bucks its not the worst deal, just don't expect to be finishing it if you aren't patient enough to brute force your way to the ending.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071224182', 'num_games_owned': 256, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1647, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1127, 'last_played': 1696833128}

author: {'steamid': '76561198061482104', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 1098, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1090, 'last_played': 1656900575}
review:
This game has a couple things going for it: Decent variety of gear, satisfying (imo) combat, subtle humor, and for someone who finds the normal rogue-like cycle of dying and losing everything frustrating and unfun, a fairly forgiving run to run cycle. I am not necessarily of the "git gud" variety, and this game doesn't punish you so much for that.

 I was able to beat this game, but after that, I don't feel very compelled to keep playing. There's not a huge amount of mechanical depth or level and enemy variety like you'd find in other rogue-like dungeoners (binding of issac or gungeon) so replayability is much lower in comparison. By far the WORST metric are the boss battles, which are fun and competent enough, but are never mixed up and by the the 3rd or so run through are just loot crates with extra steps.

 That all being said, I really enjoyed this game and think the value is totally there at the current $14, and def if you're interested and it's on sale pick it up.

author: {'steamid': '76561198153528936', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 201, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1622010138}
review: Idk, I thought this game would be something else. In the end it surprisingly reminds me of souls-likes, the key is to master the combat. The problem is the combat is really trash :) Just imagine mastering fighting 2D enemies in 3D environment, where enemies move fast, walking back is incredibly slow and space is VERY limited. The 'RPG system' exists mostly to piss you off, the higher level you are, the more difficult your next run (after you died) will be. Sounds fun? Ok, then buy it :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198032286338', 'num_games_owned': 762, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 752, 'last_played': 1606829784}
review:
Slashers Keep initially caught my eye as a fan of rogue-like (or is it rogue-lite?) games. With a premise that promised an exciting blend akin to 'Skyrim meets The Binding of Isaac,' my expectations were high, hoping for an enthralling experience.

However, despite its promising concept and potential, the game falls short in its execution, particularly in gameplay - the heart and soul of any game. The combat, which should be the driving force of excitement and engagement, unfortunately, feels underwhelming. The basic mechanics coupled with a difficulty level that seems disproportionately high, make for a frustrating rather than a challenging experience.

While the game does have its merits in other areas, they are overshadowed by the lackluster gameplay. As someone who rarely leaves negative reviews, it's disappointing to make an exception for Slashers Keep. It's a game that had the potential to be a standout in its genre but ends up missing the mark where it matters most.

author: {'steamid': '76561198039116777', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 351, 'last_played': 1621116993}
review:
Spoiler Warning:

You lose 25% of your levels, stats, and gold when you die, along with all of your held gear. I don't know why the developer decided to be so punishing. The only thing you can keep from your level ups are the abilities every so many levels. That means in order to make a death worth it, or a run worth it when you die, you have to really capture and grind as much XP as possible. You can't afford to sprint through sections to get back to where you were before, which is one of the key components of making a Roguelike respect player time, by getting them back to their milestones faster the more runs they put in. Instead, the developer decided to make it more punishing when you die by eating your levels and stats. The more runs you put in, the more costly everything is because of how much more XP you have to gain to get another level.

Lower level mobs don't give enough XP to justify making it to the first boss and getting murdered by it or murdered shortly thereafter. You really have to make sure you're scraping every bit of XP you can to avoid suffering from the level loss. It's 25% of your levels gone every death and it's not as if you get strong enough by the time your level loss on death is equivalent to the levels gained by the time you get to the spider boss. Those enemies in the first section of the game will hit quite hard and you will need to hit them through several block sequences in order to kill them. You can't quickly get through the game to return to your furthest mile stone. Your level ups do not trivialize enemies you've killed for hours and you can't afford to ignore the XP and items you've been churning through and losing for hours.

The whole thing really maximizes that treadmill grind that makes video games a complete waste of time. If it was only item and gold loss on death, then I would have less of a problem with it because you would be able to sprint through the early sections, get enough gear to make it through the first boss, and have something resembling a quick return to your previous milestones but the fact that XP and stats are lost make death so punishing that it's not worth playing. It really feels like the developer wanted to make the game give the player as little progression as possible for as long as possible.

Beyond the sheer garbage balancing, the game has some serious, glaring quality of life flaws that I'm honestly shocked weren't caught in play testing because they can't possibly be seen as fun.

First, there's so much garbage on the ground that will slow the player down. I'm not talking about oil slicks that are intended to slow the player, I mean anything that the player touches of any size is an inertia eating, black hole Kirby that will suck the player in until they're no longer touching it. Skulls on the ground might as well have a chain attached to your foot that's being pulled the opposite way you're running. Crates the size of your foot will lock you down like you're walking through a linebacker. Parts of busted crates are glue traps used to catch rats that you somehow stepped on. You get the point. Every single interactive edge in this game destroys your movement and there's crap like this in every room and hallway you encounter. It's such a terrible decision to make non-trap items slow the player down. Even the pressure plates that spring traps on you if you walk on them will slow you down as you walk around them. The only reasonable thing to do is jump over them because skirting to the side turns it into an impromptu oil slick. All the developer had to do was not make these items slow the player down and I would not have much of an issue with them.

Second, enemy attacks are abysmally hard to track. This is partly due to the medium, in that it's fake 3D sprites. The sprites themselves are 2D and they spin on the center of the object and are drawn from the perspective of always facing the player to create the illusion of 3D depth. The problem is that it's ridiculously unreliable to judge actual distances of attacks when you're moving side to side, which is the motion required to parry attacks. Enemies that can parry will auto parry, because the game's not using human beings relying on visual cues to intercept a foreshortened attack whose angle changes when you twist.

This mechanic is so unreliable that I still don't know which enemy attacks can even be parried. There's no indicator on which attacks are able to be parried and which ones are not, you just have to figure it out. Ranged attacks seem to universally land, but I think sometimes I've been able to attack them out of the air. There's a charge attack that will all but one shot you when you first encounter it. I think there's an attack the mole person does that is able to be parried but when they wind up for the side angled swipe I just get nailed by it every time, even though I can mostly reliably parry the shots from the ghouls with swords and without swords.

This is especially bad if you're on any kind of elevation change as attacks going up and coming down are not drawn to account for those perspectives. It's only ever worth parrying when on even ground. I would really like to have seen a red, 50% opacity line indicating where the enemy is going to land their attack while they wind up, because that's the point of the wind up. The wind up tells the player where to put the parry and the timing of the parry but it's so poorly communicated through the faux 3D depth of the chosen medium that I'll get hit by shots I swear I was intercepting. Having an actual line draw in the air separate from the attacking object that represents where the attack is going to be would help immensely with tracking and parrying. Plus, having an indicator for which attacks are parryable, unparryable, and which ones can be intercepted with player swings would be very helpful. It's rather surprising that these basic conveniences aren't included.

There's no dodge. There's sprinting, and there are bonuses associated with sprinting when the player lands a hit, but there's no way to slip to the side or slip backwards. Not every space you're in will allow for sprint attacks. Most rooms are cluttered, filled with movement speed destroying obstacles, and you simply don't have enough time to get around so many enemies before you take so much damage it's not worth it.

Crafting is too unreliable to be useful. Crafting components are not readily available through the course of your playing, they're not good enough to justify doing the crafting, the components and crafted items are all lost on death anyway, and they're expensive to acquire from the merchant. Plus, you have to actually find a smithy in order to craft the weapon.

Wands rely on the Intelligence stat, take up an equip slot, and provide passive stats and ability bonuses like any other piece of gear. But the way they're treated is like an occasionally useful piece of armor.

Enemies in this game all take so long kill. I legitimately stood in a room with pillars for 5 minutes to bait two skull enemies down and kill them because pillars busted their detection / pathing so much.

There's no gear protection and not enough gear to fill all your open gear slots. Marginal upgrades on gear you already have but not finding gear you don't have feels bad.

The item chute. You might think you can churn through enough gear to fill out your sets by throwing excess gear down chutes, but not really. The other uses for gear are better options than using the chute for a later run.

The inventory space is terrible. I don't think you can spin items, so throw standard inventory management out the window. I don't know how having such little inventory space is supposed to make my experience more entertaining but all it does is make the player leave value on the table.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157843554', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 390, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 340, 'last_played': 1668831298}
review:
I was honestly very very surprised by the amount of fun I had with the game.

The progression system, while slow and borderline tedious, is actually very fun and rewarding.

The map layouts and secrets, while sometimes lackluster, can be very interesting and engaging.

The combat, while sometimes punishing and slightly grindy, is often very nerve wracking and exciting.

The customization, eh.. I had a hard time getting into that.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042270191', 'num_games_owned': 2992, 'num_reviews': 139, 'playtime_forever': 1202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1136, 'last_played': 1618099560}
review:
This game is weird. The combat is a little janky and takes getting used too and your depth perception is going to be wildly off, but once you get used to it, it is an enjoyable experience if not a brutal one. It's a rogue-lite game where the gimmick is every time you die you are thrown back to level 1 and you lose some money, levels and skill points. The only thing that stays are your items that you threw down the chute otherwise what you have on your person or equipped is lost. One of the best moments was reaching a mini boss of sorts on the first level that will teach you in a subtle way that you can knock enemies into spikes with your inventory bag to kill them instantly.

The scaling feels off somehow though and almost unfair. I have finally triumphantly defeated the spider boss and got my first purple gear which was awesome and weapons that hit harder than what I was using just to go to the next level and basically get one shot by a charging enemy and any enemies that I could fight took at least 10 hits from these brand new weapons that I just obtained and would hit me like a truck despite having 2 blue pieces I just bought prior to the spider boss and that purple armor from the spider boss. It's brutal and your progression and achievements feel rewarding, but often I feel it is unfair sometimes.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995231562', 'num_games_owned': 490, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 2216, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2003, 'last_played': 1642035588}
review:
It was really hard for me to decide if I wanted recommend this game or not.  I had a lot of fun with it but it has SERIOUS problems, so I recommend reading this!

PROS:

* This game really captures the best parts of a classic action RPG when it comes to loot.  I honestly have been bored by most newer RPG loot since Diablo II.  This takes me back to that feeling.  The gear you find matters A LOT, and it's not just a pure numbers game.

* The skill system is unique and interesting.  Gone are preset paths.  Instead you get points you can use to lock in skills items provide, or a random one you get every other level.  You can choose what to pick or buff, or sit on your points hoping for a game changing skill to appear on an item to invest in.

* Creativity is rewarded.  Sure you can slash your way through everything, it's in the title.  But you can knock enemies into spikes and pits to get insta kills, if you can manage it.  You can try to even build your character around it.

* Good sense of humor.  The game makes plenty of meta jokes, from referring to your inventory in serious lore parts.  To weird posters on the wall.

CONS:

* The game relies too much on just making enemies tankier and doing more damage, rather than introducing more enemy types.  To the point that your first run with every character will be a slog every floor.  Yeah, you can sit there and block (melee) attacks to grind through it with no damage, but it takes forever - sometimes spiking things isn't an option.

* READ THIS IF NOTHING ELSE!: The middle three floors of this map RUIN the game.  Suddenly the game is full of platforming challenges, which are often REQUIRED to proceed.  There are NO platforming challenges in the floors before or after these middle 3 levels.  And that wouldn't be all that bad if it weren't for the fact the platforming is VERY BAD. 20% of the time your jump inputs WILL BE EATEN and you WILL fall.  Many of these have spikes at the bottom which do a TON of damage.  And no, I"m not just bad, I've beaten many a troll platformer in my day.  It's just bad,  doesn't work, and stands out like a sore thumb from the rest of the gameplay. [Damian please get rid of these, this game is otherwise a 10/10]

* More middle floor issues: The middle floors also have 10 times as many traps as the floors both before and AFTER it.  Rolling hallways of spikes, swinging blade traps, rapid fire turrets.  Any of these on their own is not an issue, but often they will all be in the same place and make it impossible to not take damage.  Even worse, often their will be ranged enemies that also back away from you as you get close in the hallway, making it even harder.  This is ON TOP OF enemies being extremely tanky by these floors, making it even harder to take out the ranged unit

* Ranged enemies.  There's no way to block ranged shots except for a rare skill which I've only been able to lock in on one run.  One or two two is a nice challenge, but some rooms will have like 5 moths, which are the unit that backs away from you while firing.  They can back over pits where you can't melee them, or fly too high up to melee(I haven't seen this in a bit, it might be fixed).  You may say "just shoot them", except in this game you have very limited ammo.  Which might be better used for skulls, another flying unit that almost always floats out of melee range, with some variants that never charge at you.  I think the best fix for this would be to get rid of the ammo mechanic, I could live with it, even when they're in terrible death hallways.

* Bosses are too easy.  You'll see a lot of threads from new players that "the first boss is too hard".  As soon as you know it's gimmick though it's the easiest thing in the world to beat.  Drop a bomb on it's eggs when it lays them, and kite it onto the acid it leaves behind.  I'd fight this boss 1000 times before I'd face a single moth in a spike hallway.  However the final boss is also too easy.  Unlike the first, the main villain just yells over and over at you how to beat him for one.  And again like the first, once you know the gimmick it's easy to beat without taking any damage.  Floors are MUCH more dangerous than bosses.





TL:DR - You will have a lot of fun with this game for the first 3 floors and the 4th floor boss once you figure it out.  Floors 5-7 will ruin the game for you. 8-11 you will be pleasantly confused that the difficulty seems normal again.


If you want to see more of the game for yourself before buying, I've completed several runs of the game on my youtube channel: youtube.com/lanceo90

author: {'steamid': '76561197970346768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1613676121}
review:
At first I really enjoyed the game and the difficulty of the first area and the challenge of the first boss. I eventually beat it and then moved onto the second area and it became massively un-fun.

Everything hits so hard, traps everywhere, loot wasn't much better. I just found it far to difficult to finish the first floor after the boss and when you die you have to start from the start and you've lost all your best gear so now back to the grind so you can survive it again. No thanks, such as shame as well. 

The music, gameplay and the feel of the game is right, just need to get sense of balancing as you progress. If that is fixed I will gladly come back and give it a :thumbsup:

author: {'steamid': '76561197992510435', 'num_games_owned': 441, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1610350270}
review:
The core premise of first person, 2D rogue-lite is very alluring but I found the execution to be pretty lacking.
Getting through the first area was pretty reasonable but as soon as you beat the boss and move onto the next one, enemies start doing insane amounts of damage and having gigantic health pools. Not to mention there are traps EVERYWHERE
I'm not even sure how many areas there are and I can't imagine you have to grind to get to them.

It's possible I'm somehow playing the game wrong but I don't have the have the patience or care to keep playing and find out

author: {'steamid': '76561197967061182', 'num_games_owned': 743, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1616607517}
review:
Either I'm playing it wrong, or the grind is unbelievably insane. 

Basically a "roguelike" (procedurally generated levels & items), but you keep some stats upon death. The issue is that some enemies are literally impossible to defeat unless you have good enough items. 

This isn't like Dark Souls, where you can beat the game on level 1 if you're skilled enough, it's a _massive_ grind.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976896488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 5918, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1189, 'last_played': 1678420508}
review:
It's Turbo Diablo.
It's Medieval Hotline Miami.
It's Dark Messiah of Binding of Isaac.

A slow start, but once you get a few failed attempts under your belt, the hooks are in. The art style is fantastic, combat is easily readable with characterful and distinct enemies that are fun to fight, and the skill progression system is really enjoyable, a bit like a Rogue Legacy type inheritance system but with a greater freedom of choice in how your character develops.

Swinging your loot sack around to bash enemies into spikes, bonfires and bottomless pits never gets old, either.

author: {'steamid': '76561198129332113', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 465, 'last_played': 1615276398}
review:
I kinda like this game, but it's issues are very glaring and keep me from truly enjoying it. The art style, the theme, the fragmented story you learn as you progress through the dungeon is all great, however the combat goes from okay to bland very fast and the difficulty ramps up fast. This isn't inherently bad, but it seems it's intentionally designed around preparing for your next run. This is obviously fine in roguelikes but again it becomes much more bland than roguelikes of a similar nature. You fall into a pattern of get good gear, dump good gear into chute for next run, die then try and find better gear than the gear you dumped the first time in order to dump that gear. It wears down on the player especially since most people will probably hit a wall around the first boss or the level after as, as i said, the difficulty becomes insanely hard, Enemies that look and act exactly the same then can one/two shot you. Obviously this is intentional and you're supposed to level up and get better in order to overcome the difficult levels, but without a skill tree, 3 very bland stat-booster skills, you're really reliant on gear. 

There are other annoyances such as the physics of boxes and barrels getting you stuck or wedged into hallways and flying enemies with no real way to attack aside from wasting time trying to get them to come to you or hoping you find a wand decent enough to kill them with the few charges it has. The game has these things called "challenge rooms," that aren't any different then every other room and there's no real way to tell what rooms are challenge rooms. One of these rooms had an enemy glitch through the floor causing me to become stuck as there was no way to kill them and no way to leave the room. 

I enjoyed this game for the short time I played it, but I really can't recommend it for most people. I feel the average player will hit the same wall as most people do, then get bored and move on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086638730', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 845, 'last_played': 1612794648}
review:
TL;DR. good artworks, different weapons provide variable game style.  challenging levels and bosses. have so many skills allows you to specialize your fighting style. 

I bought it for its artwork and roguelite style gameplay. it totally satisfied me. Unlike other roguelike games, you can save some of your items to have headstart in next run. at 7-8 hours of gameplay without speedrunning i completed first run. even after 10+ hours, i still discovered new items and new skills. All levels are completly randomizes so it doesnt bore at all. you can make one hit kills or parry powered characters, you can even focus on magic wands if you like ranged combat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030909358', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 185, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1614849677}
review: A game presented with charming art and music but falls flat on execution. Gameplay mechanics feel stiff and at odds with the nature of a dungeon crawler, and the physics objects in the tight dungeon rooms and corridors that get you stuck is at best very annoying and at worst, fatal.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044516568', 'num_games_owned': 212, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 1319, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 970, 'last_played': 1654283784}
review: It's a fun game but the platforming parts, stat penalties on death, and confusing map layout make the game slow and extremely repetitive.

author: {'steamid': '76561198148676717', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 541, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1614084511}
review:
Game has the shade-cell look of a Borderland game. Procedurally generated dungeons, starting loot, and enemies means every play-through is slightly different. There is a leveling system with stats but I didn't get far enough to learn more about this. I died a lot. Since it is permadeath, nothing carried over to the next play-through. Supposedly there is a drop slot for equipment that will let you use it next time. Where is it? Don't know. Attacks seem to be clicking the left button. Blocks seem to be clicking the right button. Not much more to the game than this. 


conclusion
dungeon running game with a great look to but basic combat. Good for a few hours of easy fun, as long as you don't mind dying a lot.

author: {'steamid': '76561198057049976', 'num_games_owned': 602, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 2644, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1236, 'last_played': 1650319437}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198001563415', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 1580, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 619, 'last_played': 1614491911}
review: Very fun roguelike with a good gameplay loop. Dying when you aren't prepared to, however, makes you want to stop playing the game for awhile. There's a cool feature in the game where you can put all of your items into a chute to "save" them for your next run, so dying ON PURPOSE is actually a really smart decision when you know you probably can't make it through the next section. This lets you bank all of your best loot over and over until you feel like you're prepared to go to harder levels. However, I just died to a trap room where to ceiling slowly lowers on you until you kill all of the enemies. I killed all of the enemies and died while watching the spikes retreat back into the ceiling, essentially losing hours of progress worth of gear. Because of the level progression and the way you can "permalearn" skills, I am not resetting to zero by any means, but it will likely take 10-15+ runs to get my loot back to where it was, which is super disheartening.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014351926', 'num_games_owned': 1030, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 996, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 996, 'last_played': 1613536075}
review:
SLASHER'S KEEP - QUESTGIVER'S STORY
     For days and days he slept. And when he finally woke, he looked up and his gaze fell upon a figure in the mist. The figure extended his hand and when the man reached out his hand to grasp it he was struck down, and back to sleep he went for another day or five, I don’t know. And as he opened his eyes, he yet again saw the hand extended, and once more he reached out and was struck down. And on this went: sleep, wake up, get knocked down, for a thousand days, or years. But the man’s faith never wavered, he reached for the hand each and every time. 
    And his head grew sore from the beating, and he grew a great horn on his head from where he was struck. And after some time he awoke, and he reached out, and his torturer gripped his hand tightly, and he pulled the man to his feet. And still the man spoke no ill of him. And that’s not why, instead his horn was broken off and melted before his very eyes. And it was poured upon his skin until it engulfed him whole. And then that shell of his grew darker and green and then red then finally golden. Because, you see, the man was rewarded for his devotion! And now the two stood, one before the other, as equals! 
    They stood for a day or so, until the winter came, and the man who once stood his master now bowed before him, and then laid flat on the ground face down and fell asleep. And so did all the other people of the land, as far as the man could see. And in a day’s time or a week, one by one they would wake and the man wandered around striking them down as they tried to grab his hand. And the man did his duty as the seasons passed him by until he came upon another man in autumn, who did no sleep and did not lie. And he spoke unto the man. He said “be gone”, and the man went and gone he was. And when the weather turned and thunder tore open the sky, there came an ill wind and it shoved him over; to his knees he fell. And his lids grew heavy until he fell into a deep slumber.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049368166', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 150, 'last_played': 1615859992}
review:
Slashers keep is an interesting dungeon crawler that is done in a first person view. the art style reminds me of void bastards in a way as most the enemies and textures look to be hand drawn. This game is also randomly generated in many ways besides map layout. mostly items as they are various tiers and when you die you keep some of them with you which is actually nice but it is random what stays. there is also a dropbox that allows you to deposit items to the beginning level for you to use
 >about to die and dont want to lose everything use the dropbox
>got a better enchanted item or an enchanted item you dont need dropbox and use it for the next run

there is alot to the game i have not seen yet but I have to say that the intention of the game is not to win as when you die you keep most of you skills, perks, and money you may lose 1 level from each attribute and like 4 dollars and your inventory so when you die on floor 5 you still strong enough to speed back to floor 5.

overall fun game not much to complain about other then the fact its easy to die and there arent many setting and i cant revisit the hints.

review:
第一人称动作肉鸽游戏，一旦掌握节奏很容易上头。
第三局游戏拿到了三个成就，成功的杀死了第一个蜘蛛boss，可惜第二大关被小怪在进门的地方围殴死了。

唯一美中不足的地方就是：
       没有中文！！！没有中文！！！！我看个剧情还要百度翻译！！！

author: {'steamid': '76561198009377955', 'num_games_owned': 382, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 431, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1692774410}
review:
The art style of this game is very impressive. 
When i first looked at it, I felt like it would be similar to those old dungeon crawlers I used to play back when I was a child (Orcs and Elves per example) but then, after starting the game for the first time, I realized that I could actually move the camera! ( A major upgrade to those old Nintendo DS games!)
Jokes aside, the violence is quite graphic. I mean, i pushed this giant Mole into a log with spikes, and after having it's eyes popped out ( I don't know why, poor thing) i stopped and looked at it, and was like "eyo, that's pretty hardcore."
The humor is kinda funny. I guess. Yeah.
The music is very interesting, definitely "light hearted" to what the game has to offer, making it quite comical. 
Definitely a game I would recommend my mother to play.
Jokes aside, pretty good "Damian Schloter", eager to see new updates or releases. You got yourself a fan. (or the company, i mean. It's not like i can if it was one dude or two or three who did the game, after all, it was developed and published by...)
Good job.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980787602', 'num_games_owned': 1145, 'num_reviews': 107, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1613158237}
review:
Losing levels and stats on death is too much. The more you die the more you will be thrown back in your character progression and will grinde more to get back that exp.

The combat is fun but it gets boring quickly. Charge-block-Charge-block-etc

I never got past the second floor and didn't level up above the 5th level. I just understood the game mechanics and got bored.
The game is too repetitive for my taste. Playing on the same floor XX times to gain levels only to get killed on the next one is not fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024993502', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 44277, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15130, 'last_played': 1704233070}
review:
I didn't think I'd spend over 250 hours on this one.  I was looking for a distraction and this was on sale, I saw that each level was randomly generated, and that it had a a rogue-like flavour, but included some character development and even crafting.  I expected to get my money's worth - which for me would have been maybe 20 or 30 hours.  

What I didn't expect was how well it lent itself to playing a second or third, or tenth time.  Kudos to the Developer - I think this was a hit.

Not that I didn't find some things annoying.   Getting slowed down or, caught up on small debris or on the edge of stairs introduces a level of "tedious" that wears like a blemish on an otherwise smooth experience.  I didn't hate the parkour portions, but less of that would probably be better (IMO).  

I'd give the game an honest four stars  (out of five).  It is a great reworking of the rogue theme, and has it's own charm.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975490238', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 851, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 851, 'last_played': 1607373685}
review:
The game feels genuinely nice to play, and though it’s difficult, you know you are getting somewhere, it’s exciting to think what new skill you may find next or work towards a certain build.

Its progression system is almost subtle to start with then you realise what you can do and even prepare for your next run while you are on a current run. This game came as a pleasant surprise for me, I have been watching it since EA but held off a purchase as I wasn’t convinced it was up to much and I am glad it proved me wrong.

If you want more detail on why I enjoy this title I have dropped a video review have a gander.

https://youtu.be/mcFhaoCRq3Q

author: {'steamid': '76561198017321912', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 167, 'playtime_forever': 3303, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3077, 'last_played': 1613118328}
review:
Very decent B-tier roguelike.

There are games out there that are better, like Hades or Dead cells, but if you are tired of them - try Slashers keep, it's quite worth your time and money.

Good stuff:
+immersive 3D action battles with tactical parry system
+intresting "comic'sy" sprite graphic
+variety of perks
+ability to craft super strong but silly looking weapons
+fun factor due to a bit of sillyness here and there.
+you can smack moles with a loot sack!
+the game runs well and smooth, hasn't seen any bugs in 50h playtime.

Neutral stuff:
difficulty curve - during your first run you will feel weak, miserable and frustrated. But if you continue to play the same character and aquire enough perks - you will feel like an unstoppable god of war. Snowballing really gets out of hand later on.
[strike]anime was a mistake[/strike] Second biome was a mistake. Jumping puzzles waste a lot of time and the number of spiky and thorny things is really excessive to my taste.
Just 3 main weapon types - swords, axes and maces. And due to their sheer strength most people use only the later one.
Way too many repetetive monsters, and most of them persist through the all biomes. Not enough enemy variety.

Negative:
-with levels monsters only get bulkier and hit harder but that's it. no intresting modifiers/perks/conditions, just more hp.
-hot goblin girls posters are only in the first biome!!!
-just 3 biomes, not enough details on them either. the same walls all the time are kinda sad to see.
-literally just 2 bosses. spider and the last one. Totally not enough in my opinion. 
-lack of a truly unique weapons/equipment. Like literally - there is just one truly unique weapon in the whole game - the exterminator mace.  


All in all - nice roguelike, though it may be lacking in the variety of content department. Recommended for the normal price and highly recommended during a sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028053562', 'num_games_owned': 444, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5120, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2238, 'last_played': 1676755783}
review:
This game is delightful. While quite challenging at times, it is a roguelite that never feels unfair. I'm usually not a fan of roguelikes because starting back at zero when I die is never a desirable position to be in, as I simply do not have the time to keep starting from zero until I get that sweet combination of skill and luck. Slasher's Keep seems to be made for people like me in that sense because there is character progression, and dying doesn't feel like too much of a punishment. When you die you do lose a little bit of your character progression, but it doesn't take long to get back to where you were. The art, music, voices, sound effects, atmosphere, and occasional silliness all come together to deliver a truly unique and entertaining experience that keeps me coming back. 

Oh and one other thing, the parrying system in this game is incredible and adds a deep layer of tactical gameplay that really improves combat. My hat comes off to the developer for creating such an engaging dungeon crawler which is both old and new at the same time. If you like roguelites and/or first-person melee combat, you owe it to yourself to get this game right away.

author: {'steamid': '76561199111889949', 'num_games_owned': 102, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2305, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2276, 'last_played': 1619906770}
review: Slasher's Keep is a decent enough game for a roguelite lover however can get pretty stale for someone who isn't entirely in love with that concept. at around 30 hours for me it got pretty stale but still played it because I wanted to beat it. Sadly after I beat it it didn't really seem to add many new things to the table new characters-wise. most of the skills are the same other than one different starting one and I don't see much reason to go back. however for the price point you get a good amount of time out of it, even more if you really like roguelites.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067957142', 'num_games_owned': 967, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1612713857}
review:
In its current state, I cannot recommend Slashers Keep.

The concept itself is intriguing, but the execution falls flat. After a few runs you will find yourself one-shotting every enemy within the first 3 floors, fighting the same boss which has a very simple pattern to it and then getting one-shot yourself from the first enemy on the next layer. Balancing is definitely a problem right now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035663144', 'num_games_owned': 148, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 489, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 489, 'last_played': 1606664349}
review:
Slasher's Keep has an intriguing and unique take on the roguelite genre. Unfortunately, the difficulty scale isn't gradual, and it can be extremely frustrating to die in 1-2 hits when you've reached a new milestone. 
The later levels have platforming, which hasn't been done well and is frustrating to experience. This game will rapidly become repetitive due to a lack of enemy and tile variance. The music is also terrible, sorry.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027960310', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 3351, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3071, 'last_played': 1652772164}
review: Love it, just love it. Grind to your hearts content! Once I grasped the concept, I started really enjoying this game. More enemies and level variants would be awesome, would make the grinding more enjoyable. But, within the confines of this game, I find a lot of freedom- mostly in the ability skills and the crafting. Being able to craft gear would elevate this game to one of my top 10, more monsters and dungeon variants, possibly top 5. Thanks for the great game, please keep updates rolling!

author: {'steamid': '76561198073918403', 'num_games_owned': 281, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 469, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1673075347}
review: Tons of bugs doesn't feel finished. Constantly getting stuck on the geometery of the level and jumps don't actually clear most objects you'd expect them to. Combat isn't any better than those flash games where you used to just click and celebrity would be smacked or punched. Save your money; Daggerfall Unity

author: {'steamid': '76561198072581117', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 5436, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 216, 'last_played': 1621389366}

author: {'steamid': '76561198362039859', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1998, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 960, 'last_played': 1688983487}
review:
The game looks good, it has nice combat mechanics where you actively parry the melee swings of your opponent, it has ranged weapons in the form of magic wands which are pretty lackluster and non-viable. Story is decent but not necessary, it won't affect your enjoyment of the game.

This game however has one major fatal flaw for me. It's extremely tedious and repetitive, it's not like many other roguelike games where you are pretty much guaranteed to win based on your skill level. Your character only loses part of it's perks and levels on death, meaning the game actually wants you to die countless times before making any good progress with each new character you start as.

Enemy scaling between the floors is absolutely terrible, that's where the fun gets sucked out of the game, you are going to be facing the same enemies over and over again and watch them grow absurdly in power while you remain largely the same. They will eventually have an enormous health pool and will mostly one-shot you, ending your run regardless of how far you made it in the game.

There are some things named item chutes on each floor, the items dropped inside them will be given back to you at the start of a new run. In theory it should work wonders when you have good equipment later in the game and you know you can't quite win yet. However starting with these items will only make you overpowered for the first few floors and enemies will still nearly one-shot you later.

review: Excellent rougelike game. Great gameplay loop. I like the graphics and sounds. The music is very quiet even turned up and isnt all that good. Plenty of cool skills and gear.  Crafting becomes useful in later levels.  There are a few bugs a couple which are game breaking.  Overall the game is lots of fun to play and has kept me hooked.  As of this review I have 22 hours in and have only completed the first 10 levels. I will probably triple those hours before im done playing.  This game is easily worth the price and I give it a 8/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050798398', 'num_games_owned': 839, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 848, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 848, 'last_played': 1611423419}
review:
[h1] Slasher's Keep [/h1]

Majority of the negative reviews for this game seem to be because of the jumping puzzles. Yes, they are one of the weakest parts to the game but it doesn’t deserve a thumbs down because of it. Slasher's Keep is a really fun roguelike dungeon crawler that you can easily loose time playing.

The combat having directional blocking is something I found great about this game but at later levels I just had to kite every enemy as this was the only way to defeat them. The RPG elements really helped with the replayability of the game, with all the different weapon types and perks. You can make some interesting builds. The level design for me did get stale but that’s due to there only being three different themes. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2299308168 
[b] Is the game worth buying? [/b] Yes, but they need to work on adding more content and making the jumping puzzles more diverse as they are currently boring/repetitive. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2299308204

author: {'steamid': '76561198011604006', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 2184, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2184, 'last_played': 1611504077}
review:
I've played this game quite a bit, and I was torn on whether to give it a good or bad review. It is fun, up to a point, but it's really too much work without much payoff in the long run. You'll basically run the first few levels over and over and over until you get enough levels, stats, and gear to make if farther. If you die, you lose about 25% of your levels and stats, as well as all of your gear. You do get to keep your skills, and they do help. You can save some gear for the future if you make it to a chute that sends gear to your future self. Kind of standard for a roguelike, but there are some problems.

1. It's really really easy to die, and it's not always because you played poorly. Getting one shot happens pretty often, no matter how many levels or the gear you have. This makes it easy to get caught in a loop, where you die, start a new game with reduced levels and stats, and bad gear. Then you die again almost immediately because you were undergeared and didn't have enough stats, and now you are even worse off than before. You can recover from this, but it takes a LOT of work and luck. 
2. The game isn't as smooth as you would think. It's too easy to get caught on the edge of things like steps, or barrels, or just a broken box. For a game that requires absolutely precision or else you'll get 1-2 shotted, that's not acceptable. You might even just step on or around something and get bounced up in the air. 
3. Eventually you run into plaforming/jumping puzzles. These are not fun. It's obvious they were put into the game to slow down progress, but they are frustrating. The lack of precision and control means you end up falling because you snagged something you didn't see, and you start the puzzle over.

I did have some fun playing the game, and when you are making progress, it's great. When you run into levels that are nothing but spike floors, jumping puzzles, and things like that, it's frustrating. If you play long enough and rack up enough skills, you'd likely be undefeatable, even if you died multiple times in a row, but the progress is too slow and frustrating for me. I like the first 1/3 and last 3/3 of the floors, but the middle ones are slogs that basically ruin the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198884178839', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 870, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 732, 'last_played': 1612553407}

author: {'steamid': '76561198024753734', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 238, 'playtime_forever': 337, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 337, 'last_played': 1611425137}
review: I enjoyed my first 3 hours but after that game became tedious and boring for me. Firstly I have to say I really liked the art style. I purchased the game because of it. Hand-drawn sprites are looking great. First few levels game is forgiving but on later levels enemies one-shot you. When you enter a room enemies can swarm you and you may die because of an attack you didn't see. I got one-shotted 3 times and you know what that means, gotta start from beginning. Levels are randomly generated, so expect to see same level layout most of the time. Levels are lifeless and boring because of random generation. There are some glitches. On my last playthrough I came to spider boss. I beat it but spider's corpse blocked the exit door and I couldn't progress because of it. Now this is terrible game design. I quit and reloaded my save. Because of game's stupid bug, I had to kill spider again. I said NOPE and uninstalled it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198271105938', 'num_games_owned': 378, 'num_reviews': 268, 'playtime_forever': 360, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 360, 'last_played': 1610986703}
review:
I've never played Elder Scrolls: Arena nor Dark Messiah of Might and Magic but Slasher's keep certainly feels like a game that has taken inspiration from them as in  Slasher's keep you will wake up from cell and try to make your way back on surface through random generated prison corridors facing different orcs, slime balls etc. 

During my playing of Slasher's keep I got very mixed feeling of it and felt like for every good feature the game also had a negative one.

Game's blocking mechanic is better than Elder Scrolls: Skyrim, but this game has only melee weapons and magic wands as your weapons.

You can craft weapons from different parts that you have collected during the run, but you rarely find a crafting station where you can do that.

Game has a leveling system, but only three (3) statics you upgrade. 

What finally got me lean towards giving a negative thumb was second boss. Not only does it have enormous amount of health, the fight doesn't change between runs and thus felt so boring I quit the game and felt done with the game.

[h1]Verdict:[/h1]
Slasher's keep does blocking and "push the enemy to trap" mechanic better than Skyrim, but outside of those factors I feel like I would enjoy more of a Skyrim mod that would make same things with better stealth mechanic, bigger skill-tree and with bigger cast of enemies.

author: {'steamid': '76561198084961753', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 2433, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 987, 'last_played': 1642351334}
review:
Also das wichtigste zuerst, das Spiel ist nicht wirklich abwechslungsreich und sehr grindy. Man tötet, lootet, craftet ab und zu und stirbt auch immer wieder. Das war es im Prinzip auch schon.  Mir gefällt es sehr gut. Toller Artstyle, schöne Musik.

Wenn man aber erstmal Verstanden hat, wie das Spiel zu spielen ist bockt es schon sehr. [spoiler]  Man spielt bis zu einer gewissen Ebene, dann merkt man die Gegner sind zu stark und geht lieber gezielt sterben. Das heißt man schickt seine Ausrüstung zur ersten Ebene zurück und bringt sich um. So bleibt die Ausrüstung erhalten. Leveln tut man dadurch übrigens auch. [/spoiler]
